Question 1 of
Oral Medicine
Exhibit
  • 1.

    Each of the following is a classic symptom of diabetes mellitus EXCEPT one. Which one is the EXCEPTION?

    Incorrect
    The correct answer is: D.
    92%
    Answered Correctly
    0 min, 3 secs
    Time Spent
    Question Category
    Concept

    Diabetes mellitus is a metabolic disorder characterized by hyperglycemia due to insulin insufficiency or insulin resistance. Type I diabetes mellitus is associated with hypoinsulinemia and makes up approximately 10% of all cases. In contrast, type II diabetes mellitus is associated with hyperinsulinemia and makes up around 90% of all topics. Diabetes mellitus is diagnosed when an individual has symptoms of hyperglycemia along with casual plasma glucose level that is ≥200mg/dl, fasting plasma glucose level that is ≥126mg/dl, or when A1C levels are ≥6.5%.

    The classic triad, or “3 P’s of Diabetes”, are polyphagia, polydipsia and polyuria. Polyuria, or excessive urine production, occurs due to high levels of glucose acting as an osmotic diuretic. Polydipsia, or excessive thirst, results due to dehydration from excessive urine production. Polyphagia, or excessive hunger, occurs due to the cells of the body being unable to utilize glucose as a source of energy for function. These classic symptoms are depicted in the diagram below, including other common diabetic symptoms; the symptoms in blue are more common in type I diabetes mellitus. Polymyositis is an inflammatory condition involving muscle weakness and is not considered one of the classic symptoms of diabetes mellitus.

    Therefore, D is the correct answer.

    (Image Courtesy – Häggström, 2012, CC BY-SA 3.0)

    Solution Video 

  • Patient
    Female, 41 years old
    Chief Complaint
    “I have this jaw pain that is spreading to my ears”
    Background and/or Patient History

    Rheumatoid Arthritis
    Severe Migraines

    Medications:
    Methotrexate (Otrexup®)
    Rizatriptan (Maxalt ®)

    Current Findings

    Oral exam without signs of infection. Physical examination shows mild clicking of the jaw and pain on mandibular palpation.

    2. In the clinic, the patient reports mild jaw pain with radiation to the ears associated with a sense of right ear fullness and hearing loss. She also mentions frequent episodes of tinnitus and vertigo that last several hours each. What is the most likely diagnosis?
    Incorrect
    The correct answer is: C.
    48%
    Answered Correctly
    0 min, 2 secs
    Time Spent
    Question Category
    Concept

    Ménière’s disease is an inner ear disorder that is often diagnosed clinically with a classic triad: vertigo (spinning sensation), tinnitus, and hearing loss. The components of the inner ear are illustrated below. This disease has many cross-over symptoms with other orofacial and otologic conditions as it can also commonly cause ear pain and a sensation of ear fullness. As noted in this patient, Ménière’s Disease is most often unilateral but may be bilateral as well. Additionally, this patient has a history of migraines and autoimmune disease both of which are known comorbidities for Ménière’s disease.

    Therefore, C is the correct answer.

    (Image Courtesy – Rogers, 2007, public domain via Wikimedia Commons)

    Process of Elimination

    Option A is incorrect because trigeminal neuralgia is a chronic neuropathic pain disorder that involves one or more divisions of the trigeminal nerve with a characteristic presentation of recurrent paroxysms of severe, sharp facial pain in response to innocuous stimuli in the facial region such as touch, chewing, or speaking. It is not typically associated with tinnitus, hearing loss, or vertigo.

    Option B is incorrect because Temporomandibular Joint Disorder (TMJ) may also present with earaches, ear fullness, and tinnitus, however despite the mild jaw-related symptoms seen in this patient (for which mild TMJ disease may be present simultaneously), the patient’s complaints of sensorineural hearing loss and vertigo are not seen in TMJ disease.

    Option D is incorrect because vestibular migraine is a nervous system disorder that causes repeated dizziness or vertigo, which may occur in the presence of absence of a concurrent migraine. The overlapping symptoms of Ménière’s disease and vestibular migraine include episodic vertigo and tinnitus, however sensorineural hearing loss is not typically associated with vestibular migraine.

    Solution Video 

  • Patient
    Male, 51 years old
    Chief Complaint
    “My face hurts and I can’t move the right side of my face.”
    Background and/or Patient History

    Type 2 Diabetes

    Medications:
    metformin (Glucophage®)

    Current Findings

    BP: 110/70
    Temp: 99.1 °F
    Inability to express face on right side
    Unable to close right eye
    Extra-oral facial sensory examination is normal

    3. Each of the following is a nerve branch that may be damaged on the affected side of this patient EXCEPT one. Which one is the EXCEPTION?
    Incorrect
    The correct answer is: A.
    51%
    Answered Correctly
    0 min, 2 secs
    Time Spent
    Question Category
    Concept

    The cranial nerves are a group of nerves that originate from the central nervous system and provide motor and sensory innervation to various structures of the face. Injury to these nerves and their branches can result in partial or total loss of function of the nerve and it’s structures it innervates.

    The facial nerve (cranial nerve VII) is responsible for motor innervation of the muscles of facial expression, as well as special sensory innervation to the anterior two-thirds of the tongue. As one would expect, insult to the facial nerve may cause facial palsy or paralysis, which often manifests as a lack of facial expression on the affected side. There may also be a loss of taste sensation intraorally. The image below illustrates the extracranial branches of the facial nerve and the muscles in the general region they innervate. However, extra-oral facial sensation is innervated by the trigeminal nerve (cranial nerve V) branches. The divisions of the trigeminal nerve are the ophthalmic division (CN V1), the maxillary division (CN V2) and the mandibular vision (CN V3).

    As this patient presents with lack of facial expression of the right side of the face, but normal extraoral sensation, we can assume that the extracranial facial nerve branches have been affected, but the extracranial trigeminal nerve branches have not.

    Therefore, A is the correct answer.

    (Image Courtesy – Patrick J. Lynch, medical illustrator, CC BY 2.5)

    Process of Elimination

    Option B is incorrect because the extracranial zygomatic branch is a branch of the facial nerve. It will travel across the face to innervate the facial muscles that are present in the orbital, infraorbital, and zygomatic region.

    Option C is incorrect because the extracranial buccal branch is a branch of the facial nerve. It will innervate the facial muscles of the cheek.

    Option D is incorrect because the extracranial mandibular branch is a branch of the facial nerve. It will innervate the facial muscles of the chin and the lower lip.

    Option E is incorrect because the extracranial cervical branch is a branch of the facial nerve. It will innervate the facial muscles of the neck, being the platysma, stylohyoid muscles, and the posterior belly of the digastric muscle.

    Solution Video 

  • Patient
    Male, 17 years old
    Chief Complaint
    Parent: “We are here for his routine checkup.”
    Background and/or Patient History

    Crouzon syndrome

    Current Findings

    Cleft palate
    Supernumerary teeth with crowding

    4. Each of the following is a feature of Crouzon syndrome EXCEPT one. Which one is the EXCEPTION??
    Incorrect
    The correct answer is: D.
    58%
    Answered Correctly
    0 min, 3 secs
    Time Spent
    Question Category
    Concept

    Craniosynostosis occurs in 1 out of 2500 births. It affects males twice as females and is more common in Caucasians than African Americans. While most cases of craniosynostosis are sporadic, approximately 25% are syndromic. Examples of the syndromes include Apert syndrome, Crouzon syndrome, and Pfeiffer syndrome.

    Crouzon syndrome is an autosomal dominant condition. It is the most common craniosynostosis. It often is the result of craniosynostosis of the coronal, lambdoid, and sagittal sutures. Patients with Crouzon syndrome can have intellectual disability, cleft lip and/or palate, bifid uvula, and delayed eruption in both dentitions. Interestingly, Crouzon syndrome can result in either supernumerary teeth or tooth agenesis. Another feature of Crouzon syndrome is Class III malocclusion (not Class II malocclusion). The image below illustrates the various cranial sutures. Note that the coronal, lambdoid, and sagittal sutures are the sutures often involved in Crouzon syndrome.

    Therefore, D is the correct answer.

    (Image Courtesy – Xxjamesxx, CC BY-SA 3.0)

    Process of Elimination

    Option A is incorrect because bifid uvula is a feature that occurs in about 9% of patients with Crouzon syndrome.

    Option B is incorrect because delayed eruption of primary dentition is a feature of Crouzon syndrome.

    Option C is incorrect because delayed eruption of permanent dentition is a feature of Crouzon syndrome.

    Solution Video 

  • Patient
    Female, 8 years old
    Chief Complaint
    Mother: “Her teeth are not coming in right.”
    Background and/or Patient History

    Hearing aids x2

    Current Findings

    Normal eruption pattern. Bulbous teeth with severe constriction in cervical area, radiographically teeth have almost fully obliterated pulps.

    5. What is the most likely diagnosis?
    Incorrect
    The correct answer is: B.
    79%
    Answered Correctly
    0 min, 2 secs
    Time Spent
    Question Category
    Concept

    Osteogenesis imperfecta (OI) is a genetic disorder that affects the connective tissues of bones, due to impaired collagen production. OI is also known as “brittle bone disease” and common characteristics include blue sclera (depicted in the patient’s eyes below), hearing loss, weak joints, short stature and spinal curvature. OI is associated with dentinogenesis imperfecta, in which the patient’s teeth appear brittle with bulbous crowns and a cervical constriction, as well as show pulp obliteration.

    Therefore, B is the correct answer.

    (Exhibit Courtesy – Herbert L. Fred, MD and Hendrik A. van Dijk, CC BY-SA 3.0)

    Process of Elimination

    Option A is incorrect, because amelogenesis imperfecta affects enamel formation and is not associated with any systemic abnormalities. Typically, the enamel layer of the patient’s teeth is defective and the dentin is exposed.

    Option C is incorrect, because Gardner’s Syndrome is a genetic condition that is characterized by intestinal polyps (which eventually become malignant), multiple odontomas in the skull and epidermoid and desmoid masses.

    Option D is incorrect, because hypothyroidism is defined by conditions resulting in low thyroid hormone production. Patients may experience weight gain, cold intolerance and exophthalmos.

    Solution Video 

  • Patient
    Male, 19 years old
    Chief Complaint
    “I don’t like the way my teeth look.”
    Background and/or Patient History

    Has not seen a dentist for two years
    The younger brother has similar looking teeth

    Current Findings

    Diffuse yellowish pigmentation of teeth
    Enamel is rough and unsightly
    Deep bite present

    6. Which condition is this patient likely suffering from?
    Incorrect
    The correct answer is: C.
    88%
    Answered Correctly
    0 min, 2 secs
    Time Spent
    Question Category
    Concept

    There are numerous developmental alterations that affect teeth, some being hereditary in nature, while others are locally or systemically acquired. The AMELX gene, associated with enamel protein amelogenin, is likely defective in the various forms of amelogenesis imperfecta. It may be inherited as an autosomal dominant, autosomal recessive, or X-linked disorder, which could affect both the deciduous and the permanent dentitions.

    The three most common forms of amelogenesis imperfecta are:

    – Hypoplastic type – pitted enamel surface with normal thickness and hardness
    – Hypomaturation type – enamel chips and fractures easily
    – Hypocalcified type – enamel is soft and easily lost

    Esthetic appearance is the prime concern in such cases; and restorative treatment encompassing veneers, laminates and full crowns, can help mask the condition.

    Therefore, C is the correct answer.

    (Exhibit Courtesy – Peter JM Crawford, Michael Aldred, Agnes Bloch-Zupan.CC BY 2.0)

    Process of Elimination

    Option A is incorrect, as dentinogenesis imperfecta is a hereditary developmental disturbance affecting the dentin of teeth and both dentitions. The teeth display a blue-to-brown discoloration with a translucence; and the enamel frequently separates easily from the underlying defective dentin. Radiographically, the teeth show bulbous crowns (tulip-like appearance), cervical constriction, thin roots and early obliteration of the pulp chambers and root canals. Restorative and esthetic treatments remedy the problem.

    Option B is incorrect, as dental fluorosis is generalized enamel hypoplasia, which results from the ingestion of excessive amounts of fluoride; and causes significant enamel defects. It is also known as ‘mottled enamel.’ Treatment consists of veneers, laminates and full coverage crowns.

    Option D is incorrect, as dentin dysplasia is an inherited disorder of the circumpulpal dentin, with associated alterations of root morphology. The more severe form (type I) is characterized by ‘rootless teeth’, with normally appearing crowns, obliterated pulp chambers and multiple periapical radiolucencies. The less severe form (type II) is characterized by teeth of normal color with ‘thistle-shaped’ pulp chambers and pulp stones. Treatment consists of the extraction of unsalvageable teeth.

    Solution Video 

  • Patient
    Female, 10 years old
    Chief Complaint
    Parent: “My daughter is here for a checkup. She also has a sore throat and does not feel good.”
    Background and/or Patient History

     

     

     

    Current Findings

    Temp: 100.5°F
    Malaise for 2 days
    Bilateral enlargement of tonsils
    Strawberry tongue

    7. The dentist refers the patient to their physician for the complaint of a sore throat. The patient is given a 7-day course of amoxicillin (Amoxil®), which is taken by the patient only for 1 day due to a busy schedule. The patient returns four weeks later for a new exam and complaints of pain in her knees and feet, involuntary muscle movements and a red rash on her stomach. What is the most likely cause of these new signs and symptoms?
    Incorrect
    The correct answer is: C.
    50%
    Answered Correctly
    0 min, 3 secs
    Time Spent
    Question Category
    Concept

    There is great importance in finishing the full course of antibiotics that have been prescribed. When beginning a course of antibiotics, it takes time for the medication to reach adequate concentration in the body. If a course of antibiotics is not finished, there remains a greater chance that resistant bacteria may survive, cause an even worse illness, and create bacterial resistance requiring stronger therapy.

    The patient initially presented with signs and symptoms suggestive of streptococcal pharyngitis. These include sore throat, fever, swollen tonsils, and the characteristic “strawberry tongue.” Below is an image illustrating the erythematous and bumpy “strawberry tongue” that is seen in streptococcal pharyngitis. Diagnosis is typically made by culture of throat swab (revealing group A streptococcus infection) and is treated by use of antibiotics. The diagnosis is changed to Scarlet fever in the presence of its characteristic red rash.

    When Scarlet fever is untreated or inadequately treated, it can result in acute rheumatic fever, typically presenting ~ 1 month later. Signs and symptoms include fever, rash, involuntary muscle movements, and joint pain. It can also involve the valves of the heart and cause severe damage and heart failure. Prevention of rheumatic fever by adequate treatment of group A streptococcus infection is the ideal scenario. Management of acute rhematic fever includes ibuprofen to reduce inflammation and pain, and a full course of antibiotics to treat those with positive strep cultures. Cardiac complications will involve appropriate treatment of heart failure.

    Therefore, C is the correct answer.

    (Image Courtesy – Martin Kronawitter, CC BY-SA 2.5)

    Solution Video 

  • Patient
    Male, 3 months old
    Chief Complaint
    Mom: “My son’s face has an unusual, with a big head and has trouble feeding. I am really scared for him.”
    Background and/or Patient History

    Pierre Robin Syndrome

    Current Findings

    Respiratory and feeding difficulties

    8. What components does this syndrome typically consist of?
    Incorrect
    The correct answer is: C.
    77%
    Answered Correctly
    0 min, 3 secs
    Time Spent
    Question Category
    Concept

    There are many developmental defects that affect the oral and maxillofacial region. The Pierre Robin syndrome is one of them. It presents as a typical triad of cleft palate, micrognathic mandible and glossoptosis. The image below depicts frontal (a) and side (b) views of a patient with Pierre Robin syndrome presenting with micrognathia. An infant patient suffering from this syndrome experiences significant respiratory, speech, and feeding difficulties, owing to the formation of a cleft palate and the posterior displacement of the tongue (glossoptosis). Malocclusion is noticeable as well. Abnormal facial esthetics can lead to psychosocial problems. Treatment involves surgical repair of the cleft palate, prosthetic and orthopedic appliances, and speech therapy.

    Therefore, C is the correct answer.

    (Image Courtesy – Narayanan and Adenwalla, 2021, CC BY 4.0)

    Process of Elimination

    Option A is incorrect, as these components represent the Crouzon syndrome, a rare condition characterized by premature fusion of the cranial sutures (craniosynostosis), brachycephaly (short head), midface hypoplasia (deficient maxilla), and abnormal protrusion of the eyes (proptosis). Treatment involves surgical procedures and maxillary advancement.

    Option B is incorrect, as these components characterize the Apert syndrome, which typically produces tower skull (acrobrachycephaly), retruded midface, resulting in relative mandibular prognathism, mental retardation, and fused or webbed fingers of the hand. Treatment consists of surgery, orthodontic therapy, and midface advancement.

    Option D is incorrect, as these components are a part of the Treacher Collins syndrome or mandibulofacial dysostosis. The defects typically occur in the structures arising from the 1st and 2nd branchial arches. Clinical features include hypoplastic zygomas, downward-slanting palpebral fissures, the notch on the outermost portion of the lower eyelid (coloboma), deformed pinnae of the ears, and a retruded mandible. Treatment consists of cosmetic surgery combined with orthodontics.

    Solution Video 

  • Patient
    Male, 8 years old
    Chief Complaint
    Parent: “My son is here for a checkup. His tongue is also very red.”
    Background and/or Patient History

     

     

     

    Current Findings

    Temp: 100.5°F
    Malaise for 4 days
    Bilateral enlargement of tonsils
    Swollen red tongue with white coating
    Red rash developed on back

    9. What is the most likely diagnosis?
    Incorrect
    The correct answer is: A.
    80%
    Answered Correctly
    0 min, 2 secs
    Time Spent
    Question Category
    Concept

    This patient is presenting with symptoms characteristic of Scarlet fever. Scarlet fever is an illness that is due to infection from group A streptococcus. Initially, it may present as streptococcal pharyngitis, or “strep throat.” Symptoms of strep throat include sore throat, pain upon swallowing, swollen tonsils and lymph nodes, and fever. Patients may present with the characteristic strawberry tongue, which is what is observed in this patient. The tongue is erythematous, swollen, and bumpy, like a strawberry or raspberry.

    The diagnosis is changed from streptococcal pharyngitis to Scarlet fever in the presence of the characteristic bright erythematous rash that will present across most of the body. Below is an image that illustrates this rash. Treatment of Scarlet fever involves swift administration of antibiotics to fight the streptococcal infection.

    Therefore, A is the correct answer.

    (Image Courtesy – The original uploader was Estreya at English Wikipedia., CC BY 2.5)

    (Exhibit Courtesy – Afag Azizova, CC BY-SA 3.0)

    Solution Video 

  • Patient
    Female, 43 years old
    Chief Complaint
    “I have sores and ulcers in my mouth that won’t go away.”
    Background and/or Patient History

    Hypertension
    Type 2 diabetes
    Diffuse joint pains for 7 months
    Protein and microscopic blood in her last physical 2 weeks ago

    Medications:
    amlodipine besylate (Norvasc®)
    metformin (Glucophage®)

    Current Findings

    Blood glucose: 135 mg/dl
    BP: 119/79
    Temp: 100.8 F

    Ulcers present intraorally
    + Direct Coombs test
    + Positive anti-ds (double stranded) DNA antibodies

    10. What is the most likely diagnosis?
    Incorrect
    The correct answer is: C.
    55%
    Answered Correctly
    0 min, 3 secs
    Time Spent
    Question Category
    Concept

    Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE) is a commonly misdiagnosed autoimmune disease, as the manifestations can overlap with other common conditions. A patient with SLE will typically present with a malar/discoid rash on the face from the nose to the cheek, have ulcers in the mouth and nose, and may complain of joint pain. The image below depicts a patient with SLE presenting with a malar/discoid rash of the face. Such a patient will commonly have a fever at initial presentation and may also present with proteinuria and hematuria in the urinalysis. Their blood serum will be indicative of positive anti-ds (double-stranded) DNA antibodies, positive antinuclear (ANA) antibodies and low complement levels.

    Therefore, C is the correct answer.

    (Image Courtesy – Doktorinternet, 2013, CC BY-SA 4.0)

    Process of Elimination

    Option A is incorrect because Sjögren’s syndrome typically presents with positive antinuclear (ANA) antibodies, anti-SSA (anti–Sjögren’s-syndrome-related antigen) and SSB (anti-Sjögren’s syndrome type B) antibodies. Patients typically complain of dryness of eyes or mouth.

    Option B is incorrect because Rheumatoid arthritis patients will commonly have an elevated rheumatoid factor (RF) and anti-CCP (cyclic citrullinated peptides) antibodies in the blood; in addition to joint pain, swelling and stiffness. They typically will not present with a fever.

    Option D is incorrect because Dermatomyositis/Polymyositis presents with a positive ANA (antinuclear antibodies) and skin manifestations. Patients will present with bilateral proximal muscle weakness in addition to the heliotrope rash (around the eyes) and the Gottron papule (commonly on the hands and elbows). They typically will not present with a fever.

    Solution Video 

  • Patient
    Male, 38-year-old
    Chief Complaint
    “I have painful ulcers all over my mouth.”
    Background and/or Patient History

    Hypertension

    Painful recurrent oral and genital ulcers

    Medications:
    lisinopril (Zestril®)

    Current Findings

    BP: 118/82

    0.5 cm, shallow, small, white ulcers noted at the soft palate, gingiva, buccal and labial mucosa, some in clusters and some single

    Small lesions noted on the right forearm and neck

    11. What is the most likely diagnosis?
    Incorrect
    The correct answer is: B.
    79%
    Answered Correctly
    0 min, 2 secs
    Time Spent
    Question Category
    Concept

    Behcet’s Disease (BD) is an inflammatory disease that affects multiple systems of the body. There is no known cause of this condition, making it harder to diagnose by clinicians. There are no specific labs or histopathological signs to indicate a diagnosis of Behcet’s disease. This disease commonly presents in numerous systems, with aphthous and genital ulcers, eye manifestations and other skin lesions as depicted in the scenario above. The aphthous ulcers are typically small, < 1 cm, generally painful and shallow, and typically heal without any scarring in roughly 4-14 days.

    Therefore, B is the correct answer.

    (Image Courtesy – Photographer: User:TheBlunderbuss, CC BY-SA 3.0)

    Solution Video 

  • 12. Each of the following is possible features of patients presenting with Cleidocranial Dysplasia EXCEPT one. Which one is the EXCEPTION?
    Incorrect
    The correct answer is: A.
    61%
    Answered Correctly
    0 min, 2 secs
    Time Spent
    Question Category
    Concept

    Cleidocranial Dysplasia is a rare autosomal dominant condition that is characterized by short stature, a wide face with a prominent chin, small jaw with a bulged skull cap and drooping shoulders caused by deficiency or lack of clavicles. Patients will have a delayed eruption of teeth, a more arched palate and lower jaw joints which do not unite. They will also have early closure of the coronal suture of the skull, delayed closure of the fontanels, in addition to wide pelvic joints. The features presented in the question above are all typical of Cleidocranial Dysplasia except for A, where the feature is a narrow face.

    The image below to the left shows a patient with the above-described features of the Cleidocranial Dysplasia condition; and the image on the right depicts primary teeth that are over-retained due to delayed eruption.

    Therefore, A is the correct answer. 

    (Images Courtesy: Garg and Agrawal, CC BY 2.5)

    Solution Video 

  • 13. What statement is true regarding Human Papillomavirus (HPV)?
    Incorrect
    The correct answer is: D.
    77%
    Answered Correctly
    0 min, 2 secs
    Time Spent
    Question Category
    Concept

The diagram below depicts the pathogenesis of the HPV infection cycle, beginning with latency inside an epithelial cell and ending with viruses being assembled and secreted from keratinocytes.

  • 17. Each of the following is a hallmark sign or symptom of Parkinson’s disease EXCEPT one. Which one is the EXCEPTION?
    Incorrect
    The correct answer is: D.
    63%
    Answered Correctly
    0 min, 2 secs
    Time Spent
    Question Category
    Concept

    Parkinson’s disease is a progressive neurodegenerative disease characterized by a prominent reduction and decrease in movement due to the loss of dopaminergic neurons in the substantia nigra. The dopamine levels, in the substantia nigra decrease, which leads to abnormal activity within the brain and diminished movements. The central triad of Parkinson disease includes tremors, rigidity, and bradykinesia.

    Tremors and the muscular deficiencies often contribute to poor oral hygiene thus it is important that these patients maintain frequent appointments. Common oral health issues those with Parkinson’s disease encounter include tooth decay, gingivitis, sialorrhea, xerostomia, and halitosis. Chewing and swallowing issues have also been noted due to muscular defects. Treatment of Parkinson disease includes a dopamine promoter (carbidopa/levodopa), MAO B inhibitors (selegiline), cognition-enhancing medication, and anti-tremor medication (benztropine). The diagram below depicts a dopaminergic neuron and its associated neurochemicals.

    The mood change is not a hallmark sign or symptom of Parkinson’s disease.

    Therefore, D is the correct answer.

    (Image Courtesy – Albert Maria, 2014, CC BY-SA 3.0)

    Process of Elimination

    Option A is incorrect because a hallmark symptom of Parkinson’s disease is a resting tremor. These can occur when the patient is at rest and often involve the extremities.

    Option B is incorrect because a hallmark symptom of Parkinson’s disease is rigidity. This may lead to complications such as stiff muscles and trouble making coordinated, bodily movements.

    Option C is incorrect because a hallmark symptom of Parkinson’s disease is bradykinesia. Bradykinesia is also known as slow movements. This is often characterized by the slow, shuffling gait that is often progressive over the course of the disease.

  • 20. Which is the most common chromosomal abnormality?
    Incorrect
    The correct answer is: C.
    98%
    Answered Correctly
    0 min, 2 secs
    Time Spent
    Question Category
    Concept

    There are many inherited disorders that result from chromosomal abnormalities such as a duplication or deletion of chromosomes. One of such disorders is Trisomy 21, also known as Down syndrome. This disorder occurs due to an error in cell division, which results in an extra copy of chromosome 21 being produced instead of the usual two. Children affected with this condition typically show signs and symptoms of intellectual disability, congenital heart disease (in 40% of cases), increased risk of leukemia, enlarged tongue (macroglossia), small teeth (microdontia), epicanthic folds, flat nasal bridge, maxillary hypoplasia and high frenal attachment in some cases. The image below illustrates facial features associated with Down syndrome. Patients with Down syndrome are greatly susceptible to periodontal disease and less prone to developing dental caries. These patients are usually cooperative and affectionate toward the dental staff and can be managed well in the dental office, using modified behavioral techniques.

    Therefore, C is the correct answer.

    (Image Courtesy – James, 2012, Public domain)

    Process of Elimination

    Option A is incorrect, as XYY syndrome is a rare chromosomal disorder which shows the presence of an extra Y chromosome. The affected persons become very tall, suffering from learning disabilities and other behavioral issues, such as attention deficit hyperactivity disorder and autism spectrum disorder.

    Option B is incorrect, as Trisomy 18, also known as Edwards syndrome, occurs due to an extra copy of chromosome 18.  Affected individuals, most commonly females, show intellectual disability. Cardiac anomalies are frequently observed in infants, which lead to a compromised survival. Other malformations include micrognathia, kidney problems and stunted intrauterine growth. Not more than 50% of the patients are able to survive past one week, with 90% dying within a year.

    Option D is incorrect, as Trisomy 13, also known as Patau syndrome, is another rare disorder that occurs due to an extra copy of chromosome 13. The individuals affected by this condition display severe delayed growth and intellectual disability, along with malformations of the heart and the nervous system. Cleft lip and palate are frequently seen.

    The first evidence of calcification of a permanent mandibular central incisor is between 3-4 months of age, therefore, taking tetracycline at this time is likely to have the greatest effect on the crown of a permanent mandibular central incisor. It is very important to remember the calcification dates of primary and permanent teeth, as they help to diagnose calcification defects due to local, systemic, or medicine associated etiologies.     Question Category
    Concept

    The presenting complaint of this patient, concomitant with other findings, points in the direction of burning mouth syndrome. It is a neuropathic condition, that most commonly affects post-menopausal women and comes with an altered taste sensation and dry mouth. The filiform papillae are often reduced in size and the dorsal 2/3rd surface of the tongue shows a burning sensation. Consumption of hot and spicy food tends to exacerbate the problem. The image below illustrates the lingual papillae.

The condition can be associated with other autoimmune conditions, such as systemic lupus erythematosus and rheumatoid arthritis. Diagnosis can be made by performing a biopsy of the minor salivary glands of the lower lip, or the parotid gland. Patients with Sjogren’s syndrome are increasingly predisposed to lymphomas.     Concept

    Hemophilia is an inherited disorder that affects a patient’s ability to clot or stop bleeding. The mechanism of coagulation is very intricate, involving several pathways and even more factors. The image below helps to illustrate the complexity of the coagulation pathways. Any issue at any point in the pathway presents a possibility of problems in the clotting process.In hemophilia A, the clotting factor affected is Factor VIII. Hemophilia A is an X-linked recessive inherited disorder. As males only have one X chromosome, most people with hemophilia A are male. Most patients with hemophilia A have insufficient amounts of factor VIII, while some have adequate amounts, but are dysfunctional. Symptoms include excessive bleeding, bruising, blood in stool or urine, nosebleeds, or swollen joints; while oral manifestations include frequent gingival bleeding or inability to control post extraction hemorrhage.Dental considerations when treating patients with Hemophilia A include avoiding the inferior alveolar nerve block due to the increased vasculature in the area. Infiltration, periodontal ligamental, and intraosseous local anesthesia techniques should be considered if the patient is not currently on clotting factor replacement therapy.

    25. Which test would help differentiate between hemophilia types A and B?
    Incorrect
    The correct answer is: C.
    92%
    Answered Correctly
    0 min, 3 secs
    Time Spent
    Question Category
    Concept

    Hemophilia is an inherited disorder that affects a patient’s ability to clot or stop bleeding. There are two main types of hemophilia, type A and type B. Hemophilia A involves an abnormality in the clotting Factor VIII, while hemophilia B occurs due to abnormalities in Factor IX. Both conditions are inherited in an X-linked recessive pattern, thereby affecting males more than females. Clinically, hemophilia A and B are indistinguishable. To differentiate between hemophilia A and B, a clotting factor assay is ordered. The diagram below shows clotting factors in relation to the components of blood.

    When hemophilia is suspected (either due to family history, increased bleeding or bruising in childhood, or prolongation of PT or PTT), factor assay is ordered, which involves comparing the clotting time of the patient with the clotting time once a certain factor is added. Once an improvement is observed after the addition of a specific factor or protein (for example, the addition of Factor VIII), clinicians are able to surmise that the patient is naturally deficient in functional Factor VIII.

    Therefore, C is the correct answer.

    (Image Courtesy – Sved, 2019, CC BY-SA 4.0)

    Process of Elimination

    Option A is incorrect because a complete blood count evaluates levels of different cells in the blood and helps diagnose dysfunction in organs.

    Option B is incorrect because a lipid panel evaluates different fats in the blood such as cholesterol, triglycerides, low density lipoproteins and high-density lipoproteins.

    Option D is incorrect because blood sugar levels are commonly used to monitor glucose levels in diabetics.

  • 26. Which is most affected by the human immunodeficiency virus?
    Incorrect
    The correct answer is: B.
    95%
    Answered Correctly
    0 min, 2 secs
    Time Spent
    Question Category
    Concept

    Human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) attacks a certain type of immune cell in our body called the CD4 T-helper cells. The CD4 T-helper cells help fight off infections and play an important role in our immune system. Once the virus enters the body, it latches onto a CD4 cell and fuses with it since it cannot reproduce on its own. Upon fusion, it takes control of the cell’s DNA and makes copies of itself, destroying the CD4 cell and releasing the HIV copies into the blood. HIV continues to infect and spread throughout the body. If left untreated, a minor infection such as a cold can turn severe due to the weakened immune system. The diagram below illustrates how HIV infection mediates the upregulation of molecules that inhibit T cells.

    The infected person progresses into acquired immunodeficiency syndrome (AIDS), when the virus destroys a certain number of CD4 cell, causing the CD4 count to be below 200.

    With advancements in HIV treatments and medications, many HIV positive individuals can live longer, healthier lives.

    In this case, the most affected cells by HIV are the CD4 T-helper cells.

    Therefore, B is the correct answer.

    (Image Courtesy – Larsson et al., 2013, CC BY 2.0)

    Process of Elimination

    Option A is incorrect because the red blood cells are not the most affected by HIV. Blood diseases involving red blood cells include anemias, hemolysis, and polycythemias.

    Option C is incorrect because the CD8 T cells are not the most affected by HIV. There is emerging evidence of CD8 T cells playing a role in autoimmune diseases.

    Option D is incorrect because platelets are not the most affected by HIV.  Disorders that affect platelets include thrombocytopenia and thrombocythemia.

    Concept

    There are a variety of pathogens that cause different kinds of diseases in young children. One of them is the paramyxovirus infection that affects the salivary glands. The direct consequence of this infection is mumps, which are transmissible through saliva and respiratory droplets. As many as 30% of the infections are subclinical, showing no symptoms. In symptomatic cases, the patient experiences low-grade fever, myalgia, headache, and anorexia. The parotid gland is most commonly involved. The image below depicts a patient with mumps that has swollen parotid glands.

It typically appears as a slow-growing, firm, and painless unilateral mass. Treatment consists of surgical excision of the tumor.

    Option D is incorrect, as sialolithiasis is a benign condition involving stone formation within the ducts of the major salivary glands. The submandibular glands are most commonly affected, due to their long and tortuous ductal path (Wharton’s duct). Sialolith appears as a radiopaque mass on occlusal radiographic examination. It can sometimes result in pain and mealtime swelling of the glands. Treatment consists of lithotripsy and in extreme cases, surgical removal, including the associated gland.

    Concept

    Scleroderma, also known as systemic sclerosis, a connective tissue disorder that involves autoimmunity, vasculopathy, and collagen deposition. The most common manifestation is the skin, where scleroderma causes significant sclerosis resulting in hardened, taut skin. It is divided into the rapidly progressive diffuse subtype (characterized by widespread skin involvement) as well as a more benign limited subtype (skin involvement confined to the hands and face).     Option C is incorrect because osteoma formation in the jaws is not associated with scleroderma. Rather, osteoma formation is associated with Gardner syndrome.

    Option D is incorrect because delayed healing of extraction sites is not associated with scleroderma. Rather, delayed healing may be due to a number of local or systemic factors such as medication-related osteonecrosis of the jaw, bisphosphonate therapy, uncontrolled diabetes, long-term steroid therapy, and odontogenic or periapical infection.

  • 31. What is the transmission of Hepatitis A?
    Incorrect
    The correct answer is: D.
    94%
    Answered Correctly
    0 min, 2 secs
    Time Spent
    Question Category
    Concept

    Hepatitis A is an RNA virus that may cause symptoms such as jaundice, fatigue, loss of appetite, fevers, nausea, and vomiting but is often asymptomatic as well. It is spread by fecal-oral transmission with a higher risk in travelers to regions with poor water sanitation, daycare centers, as well as shellfish consumption from viral stool contamination. Although hepatitis B, hepatitis C, and hepatitis D usually involve parenteral (blood), sexual, and perinatal transmission, hepatitis A and hepatitis E lack a viral envelope and are not destroyed in the gut. To remember that hepatitis A and hepatitis E are spread via the gut, one commonly used mnemonic is “the vowels hit your bowels”. The table below summarizes features of the hepatitis viruses.

    Therefore, D is the correct answer.

    (Image Courtesy – Nishanthb, 2009, CC BY-SA 3.0)

    Process of Elimination

    Option A is incorrect because the hepatitis A virus has a fecal-oral route of transmission and is not typically transmitted sexually. hepatitis B (and less commonly hepatitis D which usually involves superinfection or co-infection with hepatitis B) is transmitted sexually among several other sexually transmitted viruses such as human immunodeficiency virus (HIV), human papillomavirus (HPV), and herpes simplex virus (HSV).

    Option B is incorrect because the Hepatitis A virus has a fecal-oral route of transmission and is not typically transmitted parenterally. However, several viruses may be transmitted parenterally including the three most common blood-borne viruses: human immunodeficiency virus (HIV), hepatitis B virus (HBV), and hepatitis C virus (HCV).

    Option C is incorrect because the Hepatitis A virus has a fecal-oral route of transmission and is not typically transmitted perinatally. Viruses such as rubella, cytomegalovirus (CMV), and herpes simplex virus (HSV), however, may be transmitted perinatally (from vaginal secretions or maternal blood), causing newborn infection and possible birth defects as well.

  • 32. Each of the following are true regarding Herpes Simplex Virus 1 EXCEPT one. Which one is the EXCEPTION?
    Incorrect
    The correct answer is: D.
    81%
    Answered Correctly
    0 min, 3 secs
    Time Spent
    Question Category
    Concept

    Herpes Simplex Virus 1 (HSV-1) is a double-stranded DNA virus which spreads through oral-to-oral contact through both active perioral lesions and infected saliva. Close to 2/3rds of the world’s population is infected with HSV-1 at some time. After infection, the virus goes through an incubation period prior to showing the first symptoms. Prodromal symptoms involve pain, burning, and itching up to 24 hours before lesions develop. Symptoms of HSV-1 outbreak include oral vesicles on both attached and unattached mucosa, mouth (see the image below), and eye lesions. HSV-1 settles in peripheral neurons to establish a latent infection and can be triggered by many different things. Recurrence may be caused by stress, sunlight, illness, and menstrual periods in women.  HSV 1 cannot be removed from the body completely, and the purpose of treatment with antivirals is to reduce the severity of outbreak, as well as reduce the transmissibility.

    Therefore, D is the correct answer.

    33. What does a positive Bence Jones protein test indicate in this patient?
    Incorrect
    The correct answer is: B.
    82%
    Answered Correctly
    0 min, 2 secs
    Time Spent
    Question Category
    Concept

    There are various malignancies of the blood cell lineage that have oral manifestations and are commonly encountered by a dentist. The patient in this case is a 68-year-old African American, with a raised body temperature. As the lab report indicates the presence of Bence Jones proteins in the urine, multiple myeloma stands out as the prime diagnosis. It is a plasma cell neoplasm commonly associated with lytic bone lesions, hypercalcemia, kidney failure, and other abnormalities of the immune system. The radiograph below shows a forearm with multiple osteolytic lesions. This disease is commonly diagnosed between the ages of 60-70, with Black people being most affected. A swollen tongue, a sign of this disease, is due to the deposition of amyloid, which is composed of abnormal light chain proteins.

    Therefore, B is the correct answer.

    (Image Courtesy – Hellerhoff, 2019, CC BY-SA 3.0)

    Process of Elimination

    Option A is incorrect, as Hodgkin lymphoma is a lymphoid neoplasm marked by the presence of neoplastic giant cells called Reed-Sternberg cells, initially manifesting itself as a painless lymphadenopathy, followed by other constitutional symptoms such as fever, weight loss, and night sweats. There are no osteolytic lesions seen in this condition, contrary to what this patient presented with. Treatment consists of chemotherapy and radiotherapy.

    Option C is incorrect, as leukemia represents various malignancies of a hematopoietic stem cell lineage. The signs and symptoms of leukemia occur as a result of a marked reduction in the number of circulating red and white blood cells; and thrombocytes, which together, contribute to a weak immune system, bleeding tendencies, and oral ulcerations. Patients often present with a diffuse gingival enlargement, due to infiltration of the gingiva by malignant cells. Treatment usually consists of chemotherapy.

    Option D is incorrect, as Gaucher disease is an autosomal recessive disorder resulting from a mutation in the gene encoding glucocerebrosidase, an enzyme that cleaves glucose residue from ceramide. As a result, glucocerebrosides accumulate in the phagocytes, liver, spleen, and bone marrow. Patients usually present with bone pain; and radiographically, several ill-defined radiolucencies that affect the mandible most of the time can be seen. Typical deformities of the long bone, called Erlenmeyer flask, can often be recognized. Enzyme replacement therapy and genetic counseling are often employed treatment methods.

  • 34. A patient who is in her second trimester of pregnancy presents with a chief complaint of painful swelling in the lower right buccal vestibule.     Incorrect
    The correct answer is: C.
    88%
    Answered Correctly
    0 min, 2 secs
    Time Spent
    Question Category
    Concept

    Pregnancy is a delicate state in which several pre- and post-parturition complications occur. The medical history of this patient points to preeclampsia as the most probable condition. Preeclampsia is defined as hypertension, occurring concomitantly with thrombocytopenia, impaired liver function, kidney disturbances, pulmonary edema and cerebral or visual problems during pregnancy. The blood pressure often crosses the 140/90 mmHg mark, and the patient can develop swollen extremities due to peripheral fluid retention. Other symptoms comprise headache, nausea, vomiting, decreased urination, chest pain, shortness of breath and epigastric pain. Emergency medical services have to be activated immediately in such cases.

    The diagram below summarizes the pathophysiology of preeclampsia. Various factors (such as type-1 angiotensin II receptor autoantibodies (AT1-AAs), proliferation of lymphocytes, genetic factors, and oxidative stress) are purportedly associated with mechanisms that could increase risk for preeclampsia.

    Therefore, C is the correct answer.

    (Image Courtesy – Peres et al., 2018, CC BY 4.0)

    Process of Elimination

    Option A is incorrect, as ovarian cysts usually present with unilateral, intermittent abdominal pain, malaise, nausea, and vomiting, which is not the case here.

    Option B is incorrect, as ectopic pregnancy presents as mild abdominal pain, typically unilateral and sometimes with vaginal spotting. In a ruptured ectopic pregnancy, the pain is sharp and stabbing, with hemodynamic instability and maternal collapse.

    Option D is incorrect, as acute polyhydramnios is an abrupt increase in the amniotic fluid which leads to a distension of the uterus and the development of a tense abdomen, resulting in breathlessness. This is clearly not the case here.

  • 35. Which laboratory finding is elevated in a patient diagnosed with osteomalacia?
    Incorrect
    The correct answer is: C.
    81%
    Answered Correctly
    0 min, 2 secs
    Time Spent
    Question Category
    Concept

    Osteomalacia (also known as rickets when in children) is a connective tissue disorder that occurs due to the defective mineralization of osteoid (immature bone) and thus defective bone maturation, resulting in weak bones with an increased risk of fracture. Below are various images (radiograph, MRI, and photographs) of a patient with rickets that is resulting in the leg bones curving inwards. Osteomalacia is most commonly due to vitamin D deficiency, which itself is often secondary to gastrointestinal diseases such as celiac disease, gastrointestinal surgeries resulting in malabsorption, kidney disease, as well as certain medications. This state of immature bone production causes compensatory increases in osteoblast activity and thus levels of alkaline phosphatase (ALP) which are released by these osteoblasts to aid in bone maturation. The treatment for osteomalacia is vitamin D supplementation and treatment of the underlying cause of vitamin D deficiency if identifiable.

    Therefore, C is the correct answer.

    (Image Courtesy – Fletcher et al., 2004, CC BY 2.0)

    Process of Elimination

    Option A is incorrect because serum calcium levels are low in osteomalacia. Vitamin D helps to absorb calcium from the intestines; thus, calcium levels are lower in the context of vitamin D deficiency.

    Option B is incorrect because serum phosphate levels are low in osteomalacia. Vitamin D plays a key role in intestinal absorption of phosphate, thus, low levels of vitamin D in osteomalacia result in lower levels of serum phosphate. Furthermore, hypocalcemia-induced hyperparathyroidism results in further reduction in serum phosphate as increased PTH levels cause a reduction in phosphate absorption in the kidney.

    Option D is incorrect because osteomalacia is caused by vitamin D deficiency, not excess.

    Question Category
    Concept

    Sickle cell anemia is an inherited blood disorder caused by abnormalities in the hemoglobin protein resulting in decreased oxygenation to tissues. The name of the condition is based on the sickle (or crescent) shape of red blood cells caused by defective hemoglobin. The abnormally shaped sickle cells are illustrated below in comparison to normal red blood cells. The signs and symptoms of sickle cell anemia vary greatly based on the severity of illness. Some features include generalized fatigue, joint pain due to capillary obstruction, spleen damage, increased susceptibility to bacterial infections, leg ulcers, and enlarged bone marrow spaces.

    Management of sickle cell anemia is focused on pain alleviation and preventing severe complications. Sickle cell anemia cures involve bone marrow transplants.

    In the dental setting, enlarged bone marrow spaces may be noted on radiographs due to a compensatory mechanism, resulting in a loss of bony trabeculae and thinning of the cortical plates.

    Therefore, D is the correct answer.

    Option B is incorrect because multiple small and well-defined radiolucencies are not a common feature of sickle cell anemia. Rather, multiple small and well-defined radiolucencies may be a feature of multiple myeloma.

    Option C is incorrect because numerous supernumerary teeth are not a common feature of sickle cell anemia. Rather, numerous supernumerary teeth may be a feature of cleidocranial dysplasia and Gardner syndrome.

    Gardner’s syndrome is a rare genetic disorder that is characterized by multiple (hundreds to thousands) colon polyps. Other features include adrenal gland tumors, epithelial cysts, and desmoid tumors. Patients with Gardner syndrome are at a significantly higher risk of colon cancer due to the continuously increasing number of polyps that appear throughout the patient’s life.     Dental implications of Gardner’s syndrome include multiple supernumerary teeth, osteomas in the jaw, and multiple odontomas.     40. After evaluating the patient signs and symptoms, the dentist concludes the patient is presenting mumps. What is the transmission of this disease?
    Incorrect
    The correct answer is: A.
    74%
    Answered Correctly
    0 min, 2 secs

    Question Category
    Concept

    Mumps is a viral disease involving pain, fever, loss of appetite, fatigue, tenderness, and swelling in one or both parotid salivary glands. Swelling usually peaks in 1 to 3 days and recedes in 1-2 weeks. The mumps virus replicates in the upper respiratory tract and is transmitted person to person through contact with saliva or respiratory droplets of a person infected with mumps. The risk of spreading the virus increases the longer and the closer the contact a person has with someone who has mumps.

    The image shows the swelling of the parotid glands, which are located between the ear and jaw. The most common cause is mumps.

The most common cause of transmission in the dental workplace is when an infected person’s blood enters another person’s bloodstream through an open wound with a used needle.

    Option D is incorrect because fomite is any inanimate object that can transfer disease to a new host when contaminated with or exposed to infectious agents.

  • 41. Hypodontia is a feature of each of the following conditions EXCEPT one. Which one is the EXCEPTION?
    Incorrect
    The correct answer is: B.
    40%
    Answered Correctly
    0 min, 3 secs
    Time Spent
    Question Category
    Concept

    Hypodontia is defined as the developmental absence of one to six teeth with the exception of third molars. Other categories that characterize the severity of congenitally missing teeth include oligodontia (6+ missing teeth excluding third molars) and anodontia (missing all teeth). The 3-year-old patient with hypodontia in the image below presents with several absent deciduous teeth: the maxillary left lateral incisor, mandibular left first molar, and mandibular left second molar.

    The cause of hypodontia remains unclear, but is thought to be due to environmental, evolutionary, and genetic factors. Environmental factors such as infection, trauma and early drug exposure may result in hypodontia. Evolutionary influences are related to the decrease of jaw size and the consequent diminished space for teeth. There are several genes that have been associated with hypodontia, some of with include MSX1, PAX9, AXIN2, and EDA, some of which may have mutations that exist within the context of genetic disorders. Genetic disorders often exhibit multiple anomalies in addition to hypodontia. Some of the disorders linked to hypodontia include Down Syndrome, Axenfeld-Rieger Syndrome, Ectodermal dysplasia, or cleft lip/palate.

    Turner Syndrome is a condition that affects females caused by one partially or completely missing X chromosome resulting in various developmental issues such as short stature, heart defects, failure of ovary development and kidney abnormalities, among many more. Dental implications may include early eruption of both the primary and/or permanent dentition, root shortening (resulting in tooth loss), thin enamel, abnormal dentinal structure, and retrognathia causing crowding issues. Turner syndrome is not associated with hypodontia, but teeth may be lost due to short roots or other non-congenital reasons.

    Therefore, B is the correct answer.

    (Image Courtesy – Kitakawa et al., 2009, CC BY 2.0)

    Process of Elimination

    Option A is incorrect because Down syndrome is associated with hypodontia. Down syndrome is a genetic disorder caused by an extra partial or complete copy of chromosome 21, which is why it is also called Trisomy 21. Other features of this condition include stunted growth, mild to moderate intellectual disability, narrow palate, and flat head.

    Option C is incorrect because Axenfeld-Rieger Syndrome is a genetic disorder caused by abnormal development mainly affecting the eye, but systemic signs have been reported such as craniofacial abnormalities (hypertelorism, prominent forehead, underdeveloped upper jaw bones) and hearing loss. The dental implications include hypodontia/oligodontia/anodontia, microdontia, or cone-shaped teeth.

    Option D is incorrect because hypodontia is a characteristic finding in ectodermal dysplasia (ED) due to defective tooth bud formation and development. ED is a group of hereditary syndromes that are defined by the abnormalities in two or more ectodermal structures. Structures that are derived from the ectoderm include the hair, nails, skin, sweat glands, and salivary glands, which may be affected in ED.

    42. Which is an immunological hallmark of the autoimmune form of Addison’s disease?
    Incorrect
    The correct answer is: D.
    82%
    Answered Correctly
    0 min, 2 secs
    Time Spent
    Question Category
    Concept

    Addison’s disease, also known as primary adrenal insufficiency, involves deficiency in both adrenal glands and leads to severely lowered adrenal activity. The result is both adrenal cortices being deficient in production of glucocorticoids, mineralocorticoids, and androgens along with elevated levels of adrenocorticotropin hormone and plasma renin activity. These patients often present with weakness, hypotension, low body weight, nausea, abdominal pain, hyperpigmentation, and a craving for salt. The image below depicts Addisonian hyperpigmentation involving the buccal mucosa. Patients do not become symptomatic until the adrenal cortex has been destroyed approximately 90% or a stressful situation arises, requiring increased adrenocortical activity.

    The most common form of Addison’s is from autoimmunity and its cause is mostly unknown but is speculated as being a mix of genetic and environmental factors. In the autoimmune form of Addison’s, the adrenal glands are infiltrated with lymphocytes and slowly decrease in size. It is characterized primarily by circulating adrenal cortex autoantibodies that immunologically attack all three layers of the adrenal gland.

    Treatment for Addison’s disease requires medication that replaces the hormones that are deficient, usually involving hydrocortisone taken orally every day.

    Therefore, D is the correct answer.

    (Image Courtesy – Mosca et al., 2021, CC BY 4.0)

    Process of Elimination

    Option A is incorrect because IgM levels are not a hallmark of Addison’s disease.

    Option B is incorrect because Addison’s disease does not affect the thyroid.

    Option C is incorrect because high lymphocyte concentrations are often found in the adrenal cortex in Addison’s disease.

    43. Which is the medical emergency representing these symptoms?
    Incorrect
    The correct answer is: C.
    67%
    Answered Correctly
    0 min, 2 secs
    Time Spent
    Question Category
    Concept

    Myxedema coma is the most severe form of hypothyroidism and is a life-threatening emergency. It is often triggered by cold weather, infection, overdose of medications that can suppress respiratory drive, myocardial infarction, trauma, and many other factors. History of hypothyroidism helps in diagnosis of this emergency, but may be undiagnosed, so thorough medical history is required if possible. In this case, we know our patient is being treated for hypothyroidism with levothyroxine. Other etiologies to look for include pituitary or hypothalamic disease, dry skin, sparse hair, hoarseness, macroglossia, periorbital edema, nonpitting edema of the hands and feet, delayed deep tendon reflexes, altered mental status, surgical scar traversing the neck, bradycardia, hypothermia, and hypotension. The image below summarizes signs and symptoms that characterize hypothyroidism. Lab values will often show hypoglycemia from lowered metabolism and gluconeogenesis, elevated serum creatinine, elevated creatine kinase, elevated lactate dehydrogenase, hyperlipidemia, anemia, or mild leukopenia.

    While rare, myxedema is highly dangerous and of concern in elderly women with aforementioned signs and symptoms, as hypothyroidism disproportionately affects women and myxedema is a complication that arises usually after years of hypothyroidism.

    Therefore, C is the correct answer.

    (Image Courtesy – Häggström, 2014, CC0 1.0)

    Process of Elimination

    Option A is incorrect because the presenting symptoms do not point to a stroke (stroke symptoms can be remembered with the acronym FAST, or facial drooping, arm weakness, speech difficulties, and time)

    Option B is incorrect because these symptoms more likely point to myxedema than hypoglycemia (patient more likely to present with a fast heartbeat, sweating, hunger, and shakiness)

    Option D is incorrect because vasovagal syncope would more likely present with the patient feeling dizzy, drowsy, weak, or lightheaded and subsequently passing out.

    44. Which is the most common malignancy of the oral cavity?
    Incorrect

    Answered Correctly
    0 min, 2 secs
    Time Spent
    Question Category
    Concept

    The vast majority of cancer diagnoses in the head and neck region is squamous cell carcinoma (SCC), which accounts for approximately 90% of all head and neck cancers. Furthermore, SCC is responsible for 3% of all cancer diagnoses and 1.6% of all cancer deaths. Interestingly, in recent years, there has been a statistically significant increase in oropharyngeal SCC of the tonsil and oropharynx, while a statistically significant decrease in SCC of the floor of the mouth, lip, and hypopharynx.

    In recent years, it is estimated that there are 51,540 new annual cases of SCC of the head and neck, and 10,030 annual SCC of the head and neck-related death.

    The image below demonstrates a classic oral presentation of squamous cell carcinoma. Note that the lateral aspects of the tongue and the floor of the mouth are common sites of oral squamous cell carcinomas.

    Therefore, C is the correct answer.

    (Image Courtesy – Welleschik, CC BY-SA 3.0)

    Process of Elimination

    Option A is incorrect because granular cell tumor is a benign tumor of the tongue. It typically appears as a dome-shaped swelling of the dorsal tongue. Even though granular cell tumors can sometimes mimic an SCC due to the accompanying changes in the epithelium, it is not a malignancy like SCC.

    Option B is incorrect because a mucoepidermoid carcinoma is a salivary gland tumor, and only about 50% of all intraoral salivary gland tumors are malignant.     Option D is incorrect because adenoid cystic carcinoma is a salivary gland tumor, and only about 50% of all intraoral salivary gland tumors are malignant. Microscopically, adenoid cystic carcinomas have a characteristic cribriform appearance. It is often painful due to its tendency to infiltrate around nerves.

    47. Which human papillomavirus (HPV) is commonly associated with HPV-positive oropharyngeal squamous cell carcinoma?

    Question Category
    Concept

    Squamous cell carcinoma (SCC) is the most common malignancy of the head and neck region. Oral cavity SCC and oropharynx SCC accounts for 90% of cancers in the head and neck region, and share many common features, including many of the identified major risk factors. Interestingly, human papillomavirus (HPV) infection is a major risk factor for oropharyngeal cancer, but not oral cancer. The image below shows a close-up of cancer formation in the oropharynx.

    There are various types of HPV viruses, and approximately 85 to 90% of HPV-positive oropharyngeal squamous cell carcinoma are caused by HPV-16 and HPV-18. HPV-16 and HPV-18 are high-risk types of HPV virus, and nodal metastases are present in about 80 to 85% of all HPV-positive oropharyngeal squamous cell carcinomas.

    Option C is incorrect because HPV-11 is a low-risk type of HPV. HPV-11 can induce epithelial proliferation and cause squamous papilloma.

  • 50. Ketoacidosis is most likely to present in which kind of patient? 
    Incorrect
    The correct answer is: C.
    79%
    Answered Correctly
    0 min, 2 secs
    Time Spent
    Question Category
    Concept

    Ketoacidosis occurs when insulin does not allow blood sugar into cells. Glucose supplies energy to the cells and when it can not be transported into the cell, they look elsewhere for power. This causes the liver to start breaking down fat into acids called ketones. If the body has too many ketones produced too quickly, then acid levels can build up to dangerous amounts leading to a condition known as ketoacidosis.

    Ketoacidosis commonly occurs in those with hyperglycemia since these are patients with the diagnosis of diabetes. These patients often have issues with their insulin working properly which prevents glucose from entering cells. This makes them more susceptible to a build-up of ketones in the body which can lead to ketoacidosis. 

    Therefore, C is the correct answer.

  • 53. What is the inheritance pattern of dentinogenesis imperfecta?
    Incorrect
    The correct answer is: A.
    76%
    Answered Correctly
    0 min, 2 secs
    Time Spent
    Question Category
    Concept

    Dentinogenesis imperfecta is an anomaly of tooth development characterized by undermineralization of dentin which results in opalescent teeth with a blue-gray or yellow-brown discoloration, affecting both primary and permanent dentitions. Examples of this inheritance include sickle cell anemia and cystic fibrosis.

    Option C is incorrect because X-linked inheritance refers to genetic traits where a single mutated gene on the X chromosome is transmitted from parent to child. Examples of X-linked conditions include color blindness and hemophilia A.

    Option D is incorrect because Y-linked inheritance refers to mutations carried on the Y chromosome and transmitted from father to son only. Examples of this inheritance include hypertrichosis of ears (hairy ears).

    54. What is the most likely diagnosis of these dermatologic findings?
    Incorrect
    The correct answer is: B.
    74%
    Answered Correctly
    0 min, 3 secs
    Time Spent
    Question Category
    Concept

    Basal cell carcinoma is the most common type of skin cancer with a median age of diagnosis of over 65 years old. One key risk factor is repeated and unprotected sun exposure (UV radiation). Unlike other skin cancers, such as melanoma, it has a low predilection for metastasis, however, it is locally invasive. As shown in the image below, basal cell carcinomas classically present as pink nodules, often described as “waxy” or “pearly”, with ulcerations or crusting in the center of the lesion. As in this scenario, these lesions are often associated with telangiectasia (small, dilated blood vessels near the skin’s surface). When basal cell carcinoma presents at a much younger age, there is a much higher suspicion for a genetic component to the malignancy. Basal cell carcinomas are risk-stratified based on size and cellular pathology after biopsy, however, treatment is most often with surgery (either wide-excision or Mohs micrographic surgery). This patient’s constellation of oral findings (removal of multiple odontogenic keratocysts), ophthalmologic findings (history of congenital blindness), neurologic findings (intellectual disability), and dermatologic findings (likely basal cell carcinoma), are consistent with Gorlin-Goltz syndrome, a rare autosomal dominant inherited syndrome. Basal cell carcinoma in Gorlin-Goltz syndrome develops at a median age of 20 years old. 

    Therefore, B is the correct answer.

    (Image Courtesy – OpenStax College, CC BY 3.0)

    Process of Elimination

    Option A is incorrect because squamous cell carcinomas, though often associated with recurrent sun exposure, are not associated with Gorlin Goltz Syndrome and the removal of multiple OKCs. Squamous cell carcinoma is the second most common skin cancer (after basal cell carcinoma) and often arises from actinic keratosis (AK), benign skin lesions that arise due to years of repeated sun exposure. Squamous cell carcinoma most often affects the face, ears, hands, and lower lip (compared to basal cell carcinoma which more commonly affects the upper lip). 

    Option C is incorrect because melanoma is not associated with Gorlin Goltz Syndrome and the removal of multiple OKCs. Melanoma is a malignant skin lesion of melanocytes that often begins as benign nevi (moles) progressing to dysplastic nevi and eventually presenting as irregular, hyperpigmented lesions. Compared to basal cell carcinoma, it has a much higher predilection for metastasis. 

    Option D is incorrect because keratoacanthoma is associated with Gorlin Goltz Syndrome and the removal of multiple OKCs. Keratoacanthoma, rather, is a rapidly growing and often spontaneously regressing skin lesion that presents with keratin-filled, dome-shaped nodules.

  • 55. Which condition is characterized by dwarfism with macrocephaly, frontal bossing, and frequent ear infection?
    Incorrect
    The correct answer is: C.
    71%
    Answered Correctly
    0 min, 2 secs
    Time Spent
    Question Category
    Concept

    Bone formation occurs through two key processes: endochondral ossification and membranous ossification. Endochondral ossification involves lamellar bone formed from a cartilaginous matrix precursor and constitutes formation of the appendicular and axial skeletons. Contrarily, membranous ossification occurs without the formation of such a matrix and forms the bones of the face, calvarium, and the clavicle. Achondroplasia is a genetic disorder caused by an autosomal dominant mutation of  FGFR3 (fibroblast growth factor receptor 3) on chromosome 4. It is the most common cause of dwarfism and is due to defective endochondral ossification, thus resulting in short limbs due to improper growth of long bones. Because membranous ossification is unaffected, the skull is relatively large, and patients are thus found to have large heads relative to their limbs. As shown in the image below, macrocephaly and frontal bossing (large forehead) are also thought to result from direct FGFR3-mediated effects on brain and skull morphogenesis. Patients may also present with frequent ear infections due to eustachian tube blockage. 

    Therefore, C is the correct answer.

    (Image Courtesy – US Federal Government, Public domain)

    Process of Elimination

    Option A is incorrect because dwarfism with macrocephaly, frontal bossing, and frequent ear infections are inconsistent with osteogenesis imperfecta, a congenital disorder of collagen production that leads to brittle bones and frequent fractures. 

    Option B is incorrect because dwarfism with macrocephaly, frontal bossing, and frequent ear infections are inconsistent with Paget’s disease of bone, a disease of abnormal bone remodeling. Although Paget’s disease of bone may present with bone enlargement (including frontal bossing), it is not a cause of dwarfism.

    Option D is incorrect because dwarfism with macrocephaly, frontal bossing, and frequent ear infections are inconsistent with osteopetrosis, a genetic disease of defective osteoclast activity causing failure of normal bone resorption and thickened, fracture-prone bones. 

    Solution Video

    Concept

    There are several working hypotheses that explain why biologic females can better distinguish color (and even see a wider range of colors) than males. Hypotheses include evolutionary adaptations, inherent genetics of the X chromosome, and developmental implications of higher testosterone levels during visual cortex formation. Although there are clear gender differences in the epidemiology of alcohol use and alcohol use disorder between males and females, especially with respect to binge drinking behaviors which are twice as likely in males, cumulative lifetime alcohol consumption has not been linked to the differential color distinction in men and women.

    Process of Elimination

    Option B is incorrect because inherent genetic differences in the X and Y chromosomes is a possible theory for why females can better distinguish colors than males. Research has shown that the X chromosome has a larger role in the genetic coding of cones (particularly the red and green pigments), thus, this hypothesis proposes that females with two X chromosomes may have a larger variety of cone activation. 

    Option C is incorrect because the developmental hormonal differences between males and females, particularly the higher levels of testosterone during formation of the brain’s visual cortex, is one proposed explanation for why females can better distinguish colors than males.

  • 76. What does the presence of anti-HBs indicate?
    Incorrect
    The correct answer is: C.
    63%
    Answered Correctly
    0 min, 2 secs
    Time Spent
    Question Category
    Concept

    Hepatitis B is a DNA hepadnavirus that is transmitted sexually, perinatally, and through contact with blood and other body fluids. Like other hepatitis viruses, hepatitis B (or HepB) is primarily a liver infection that causes symptoms such as fever, jaundice, fatigue, and severe elevations of liver enzymes (ALT and AST) on laboratory testing. Laboratory testing for hepatitis serology markers is a useful tool in determining the status of HepB infection. The HepB virus contains a “surface antigen” (HBsAg), “E antigen” (HBeAg), and “core antigen” (HBcAg). The presence of anti-Hbs indicates immunity via vaccination or previous infection and consequent recovery.

  • 77. A mother and father are both positive for the sickle cell trait. What is the likelihood that their first child will be born with sickle cell anemia?
    Incorrect
    The correct answer is: B.
    54%
    Answered Correctly
    0 min, 2 secs
    Time Spent
    Question Category
    Concept

    Sickle cell anemia is a hematologic disease characterized by abnormal red blood cell morphology. It is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern. With the presence of two copies for the hemoglobin gene, one from each parent, it is possible to have two diseased alleles (sickle cell anemia), one diseased allele (a milder form of disease known as sickle cell trait), or zero diseased alleles (healthy individuals). The probability that a child will be born with sickle cell anemia represents the probability that they inherit the diseased gene from both parents. For parents with sickle cell trait, there is a 50% probability of passing on the disease’s allele. Thus, multiply the 50% probability of inheritance from one parent by a 50% probability of inheritance from the other parent, the probability of inheriting two diseased genes is 25%. The autosomal recessive inheritance pattern is illustrated in the image below.

    Therefore, B is the correct answer.

    (Image Courtesy – Domaina, Kashmiri and SUM1, CC BY-SA 3.0)

    Process of Elimination

    Option A is incorrect because the probability of sickle cell anemia (two diseased genes) in a child whose parents both have sickle cell trait (one diseased gene each) is 25%, not 0%. However, if only one parent has sickle cell trait, the probability that a child has sickle cell disease will be near 0%.

    Option C is incorrect because the probability of sickle cell anemia (two diseased genes) in a child whose parents both have sickle cell trait (one diseased gene each) is 25%, not 50%.

    Option D is incorrect because the probability of sickle cell anemia (two diseased genes) in a child whose parents both have sickle cell trait (one diseased gene each) is 25%, not 100%. However, if both parents have sickle cell anemia, the probability that a child also has sickle cell anemia would be near 100%.

  • 82. Each of the following is a pattern of Mendelian inheritance EXCEPT one. Which one is the EXCEPTION?
    Incorrect
    The correct answer is: B.
    77%
    Answered Correctly
    0 min, 3 secs
    Time Spent
    Question Category
    Concept

    Mendelian inheritance collectively refers to the patterns of how genetic traits are passed on from the parents to the offspring. The principles of Mendelian inheritance involve autosomal dominant, autosomal recessive, and sex-linked patterns. Somatic mutation refers to an alteration at the cellular level which occurs after fertilization is complete. These mutations are not passed on from the parents to the offspring and are a part of the normal aging process. They do not contribute to Mendelian inheritance. 

    Therefore, B is the correct answer.

    Process of Elimination

    Option A is incorrect, as the autosomal dominant pattern of inheritance is a component of Mendelian inheritance. In this pattern, only one chromosome in the pair needs to have the gene defect for the trait to manifest in an offspring. The affected parent has a 50% chance of transmitting the mutated gene to their child. Some examples in dentistry include dentinogenesis imperfecta, achondroplasia, and Marfan syndrome. 

    Option C is incorrect as the autosomal recessive pattern is another component of Mendelian inheritance. In this pattern, the affected child inherits one copy of the defective gene from each parent for the disease to manifest itself. There is only a 25% chance that the offspring will inherit both mutant copies of the gene. Examples include ectodermal dysplasia and some forms of amelogenesis imperfecta. 

    Option D is incorrect, as sex-linked genes occur on either the X or the Y chromosome and form a part of the Mendelian inheritance. Only males can inherit the Y-linked genes. The traits present on the X chromosome make the sons have a 50% probability of inheriting the defective gene from their mother and showing the disease. If the daughter is a recipient of the defective gene, she becomes a carrier of the disease and usually displays a mild phenotype. Some examples include fragile X syndrome and hypohidrotic ectodermal dysplasia. 

    Solution Video
