    83.  Which type of viral hepatitis does not have a chronic carrier state?
    Incorrect
    The correct answer is: C.
    60%
    Answered Correctly
    0 min, 2 secs
    Time Spent
    Question Category
    Concept

    Hepatitis is the inflammation of the liver and is most commonly caused by a virus. Other causes of hepatitis include chronic alcoholism, toxins, certain medications, and some medical conditions. Chronic viral hepatitis is the predominant cause of liver cirrhosis and liver carcinoma in the U.S. Hepatitis A chiefly transmits through the fecal-oral route and usually does not result in chronic infection. It does not have a chronic carrier state. Cases usually resolve on their own within 4-7 weeks with only mild to moderate symptoms like fever, malaise, fatigue, and loss of appetite. Vaccines are available to prevent Hepatitis A infection.

    Therefore, C is the correct answer.

    Process of Elimination

    Option A is incorrect, as hepatitis D, also known as “delta hepatitis,” is caused by the hepatitis D virus. It only occurs in people who are already infected with the hepatitis B virus. It is transmitted through contaminated blood and other body fluids from an infected person. Chronic hepatitis B carriers contract the hepatitis D virus resulting in a serious co-infection. In a sense, hepatitis D does have a chronic carrier state, just like hepatitis B. 

    Option B is incorrect, as hepatitis C is the most common bloodborne infection in the U.S. and is the leading cause of liver transplants. It is known to have a chronic carrier state just like hepatitis B, and there is no vaccine for hepatitis C at present. Despite the non-availability of a vaccine, current treatment regimens are able to treat more than 90% of the cases. 

    Option D is incorrect, as hepatitis B is a liver infection caused by the hepatitis B virus. It is a vaccine-preventable infection and is known to have a chronic carrier state. The hepatitis B virus is a bloodborne pathogen and is an occupational risk to individuals exposed to blood, blood products, or other bodily fluids. When present chronically, it can lead to liver failure and liver cancer.

  • 85. Which is true regarding Type I diabetes?
    Incorrect
    The correct answer is: A.
    94%
    Answered Correctly
    0 min, 2 secs
    Time Spent
    Question Category
    Concept

    Type I diabetes occurs when the pancreas produces little or no insulin through the progressive loss of pancreatic beta cells. Type I diabetes usually occurs in children or young adults. Common symptoms include an increased thirst, increased urination, elevated hunger levels, weight loss, fatigue, and blurred vision. There is no cure for Type I diabetes, however there are ways to manage it by taking insulin to compensate for the body being unable to produce its own supply. 

    There are three main types of pancreatic cells which include beta cells, delta cells, and alpha cells. The pancreas also has gamma cells and epsilon cells, but they play a lesser role in the organ. The beta cells are primarily responsible for producing insulin and are progressively lost in those who have type I diabetes.  

    Therefore, A is the correct answer.

    Process of Elimination

    Option B is incorrect since type I diabetes is primarily impacted by the decrease or complete depletion of insulin production in the patient. This involves the progressive loss of beta cells in the pancreas since these cells make insulin. Delta cells in the pancreas produce somatostatin which suppresses the release of other hormones in the pancreas. 

    Option C is incorrect since type I diabetes is primarily impacted by the decrease or complete depletion of insulin production in the patient. This involves the progressive loss of beta cells in the pancreas since these cells make insulin. Alpha cells in the pancreas produce glucagon which raises blood glucose levels in the body. 

    Option D is incorrect since type I diabetes is primarily impacted by the decrease or complete depletion of insulin production in the patient. This involves the progressive loss of beta cells in the pancreas since these cells make insulin. Epsilon cells in the pancreas produce ghrelin which stimulates hunger.

  • 87.  Each of the following is a correct statement regarding X-linked hypophosphatemia EXCEPT one. Which one is the EXCEPTION?
    Incorrect
    The correct answer is: A.

    Answered Correctly
    0 min, 2 secs
    Time Spent
    Question Category
    Concept

    X-linked hypophosphatemia, also known as vitamin D-resistant rickets, is an inherited bone disorder that typically shows reduced phosphate levels in the blood and results in phosphate wasting leading to soft and weak bones. Clinical signs and symptoms include short stature, bowed legs, bent spine, and bone pain. In 2018, the U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA) approved a monoclonal antibody, burosumab-twza (Crysvita®), which inhibits the activity of fibroblast growth factor 23, resulting in the normal processing of phosphate in the body. Asfotase alfa (Strensiq®) was approved by the FDA in 2015 as an enzyme replacement therapy for hypophosphatasia, NOT X-linked hypophosphatemia. The image below shows a radiograph of a 2-year-old patient suffering from the disease and having bowed legs. 

    Therefore, A is the correct answer. 

    (Image Courtesy – Michael L. Richardson, M.D. Sept 28th, CC BY-SA 1.0)

    Process of Elimination

    Option B is incorrect, as X-linked hypophosphatemia results from mutations in the PHEX gene on the X chromosome. It is an X-linked dominant inheritance. The condition affects at least 3000 children and 12,000 adults in the U.S. every year. 

    Option C is incorrect, as spontaneous dental abscesses are commonly seen in patients suffering from X-linked hypophosphatemia (vitamin D-resistant rickets). The structural changes that occur in the enamel and dentin, the presence of large pulp chambers, and the extension of the pulp horns to the dentinoenamel junction, result in pulpal exposure and dental abscesses. 

    Option D is incorrect, as the presence of low levels of phosphate in the blood is a characteristic feature of X-linked hypophosphatemia.

    Incorrect
    The correct answer is: C.

    Answered Correctly
    0 min, 2 secs
    Time Spent
    Question Category
    Concept

    Malampati classification is used by anesthesiologists to determine the ease of intubation while sedating a patient. This classification is also used to predict the possibility of obstructive sleep apnea in a patient. It consists of 4 classes: 

    • Class I = the soft palate, and entire uvula are visible
    • Class II = the soft palate, hard palate, and upper portion of the uvula are visible
    • Class III = the soft palate, hard palate, and base of the uvula are visible
    • Class IV = only the hard palate is visible

    Class I indicates the best prediction, while Class IV suggests the worst. The image below represents Classes I – IV of the Mallampati classification.

    Therefore, C is the correct answer.

  • 96.  Each of the following is a clinical form of hypophosphatasia EXCEPT one. Which one is the EXCEPTION?
    Incorrect
    The correct answer is: C.
    60%
    Answered Correctly
    0 min, 2 secs
    Time Spent
    Question Category
    Concept

    Hypophosphatasia is an uncommon inherited disorder of metabolism which occurs due to a mutation in the gene that encodes the tissue-nonspecific alkaline phosphatase enzyme (TNAP). The condition is characterized by defective bone and tooth mineralization, weakness, seizures, respiratory distress, and sometimes death. Oral manifestations include premature loss of deciduous teeth, dental caries, improperly formed teeth, and alveolar bone loss. There are six clinical forms of hypophosphatasia: perinatal lethal, perinatal benign, infantile, childhood/juvenile, adult, and odontohypophosphatasia. There is no such form called senile hypophosphatasia. These forms can often overlap and show similar characteristics. The radiographic image below shows a case of hypophosphatasia with the patient missing their lower permanent incisors.

    Therefore, C is the correct answer. 

    (Image Courtesy – Martin James et al. Int J Implant Dent 5, 15 (2019), CC BY-SA 4.0)

    Process of Elimination

    Option A is incorrect, as the perinatal form of hypophosphatasia is further divided into two forms: lethal and benign. The former is an autosomal recessive condition, while the latter is an autosomal dominant subtype. The lethal form is characterized by hypomineralization and osteochondral bone spurs, while the benign form exhibits the bowing of long bones and runs a benign postnatal course. 

    Option B is incorrect, as the infantile form of hypophosphatasia is an autosomal recessive trait marked by craniosynostosis, rachitic ribs, hypomineralization, and hypercalciuria. There is also a premature loss of deciduous teeth. 

    Option D is incorrect, as the adult form of hypophosphatasia could either manifest as an autosomal dominant or an autosomal recessive trait. The bones can undergo stress fractures, especially the tibia and metatarsals, and patients often suffer from osteoarthritis. Dental symptoms may be present or absent.

    Sjögren disease is an autoimmune condition affecting the lacrimal and salivary glands most prominently producing dry eyes and mouth.     Concept

    HIV is a bloodborne pathogen and the best way to prevent transmission of HIV in the dental setting is to avoid blood and bodily fluids from individuals infected with HIV. When exposure occurs, antiretroviral medications can be prescribed within the first 72 hours of exposure in order to help reduce the risk of an actual HIV infection. However, the sooner the antiretroviral medication is started, the lower the risk of an actual infection.   • 99. Which is the gold standard in the assessment of glycemic control?
    Incorrect
    The correct answer is: B.
    82%
    Answered Correctly
    0 min, 2 secs
    Time Spent
    Question Category
    Concept

    Those with type I diabetes and type II diabetes must monitor their glucose levels. There is an assortment of tests that can monitor glucose levels in the blood. The gold standard assessment is the glycosylated hemoglobin test or commonly called the A1c value. This test measures the average blood glucose level in an individual over two or three months. An A1c value below 5.7% is normal, and a value between 5.7-6.4% indicates prediabetes. A value over 6.5% indicates that the patient has diabetes. 

    Therefore, B is the correct answer.

    Process of Elimination

    Option A is incorrect because the gold standard assessment is the glycosylated hemoglobin test or the A1c value. The fasting blood sugar test measures the sugar in blood overnight when the patient is not eating. A blood sugar level of 99mg/dL is lower than normal. 100-125 mg/dL is in the prediabetes range. A value of 126 mg/dL indicates diabetes.

    Option C is incorrect because the gold standard assessment is the glycosylated hemoglobin test or the A1c value. A glucose tolerance test measures glucose in the blood before and after the patient has drunk a liquid containing glucose.

    Option D is incorrect because the gold standard assessment is the glycosylated hemoglobin test or the A1c value. A urine glucose test measures the amount of glucose found in a urine sample by the patient. The presence of glucose in the urine is called glucosuria.

  • 104. Each of the following is a health complication associated with obstructive sleep apnea EXCEPT one. Which one is the EXCEPTION?

    Time Spent
    Question Category
    Concept

    Obstructive sleep apnea results in the narrowing of the upper airway causing either partial or complete cessation of airflow. Apneic episodes usually last between 10-30 seconds but may be up to 60 seconds in duration. Various short-term and long-term health complications are associated with obstructive sleep apnea, the most common being hypertension or high blood pressure.     Option B is incorrect, as dementia is an associated health complication of obstructive sleep apnea.

    Option C is incorrect, as increased cancer incidence and mortality is an associated health complication of obstructive sleep apnea.

    0 min, 2 secs
    Time Spent
    Question Category
    Concept

    When non-surgical treatment fails to resolve the symptoms of severe obstructive sleep apnea, it is prudent to adopt surgical management of the condition. The surgical procedures are primarily intended to manipulate and adjust the bone and soft tissues, reduce upper airway obstruction, or sometimes implant neurostimulator devices. Of all the surgical interventions listed above, the Millard technique is not a surgical intervention for obstructive sleep apnea. It is used to repair a unilateral cleft of the lip by employing a rotation-advancement mucocutaneous flap method. The image below shows uvulopalatopharyngoplasty for the management of obstructive sleep apnea.

    Therefore, C is the correct answer. 

    (Image Courtesy – Drcamachoent, CC BY-SA 4.0)

    Process of Elimination

    Option A is incorrect, as uvulopalatopharyngoplasty is a surgical procedure carried out to rearrange the uvula, palate, and throat wall to increase the size of the upper airway and reduce tissue collapse.

    Option B is incorrect, as tracheostomy is another surgical intervention used to treat obstructive sleep apnea. An incision is made in the anterior neck region to keep the trachea open through a tube having a valve. This valve can be closed while speaking and breathing normally. Tracheostomy is a disfiguring procedure, hence utilized for severe cases of obstructive sleep apnea.

    Option D is incorrect, as maxillary-mandibular advancement is used to relieve the symptoms of obstructive sleep apnea. It helps expand the patient’s upper and lower pharyngeal airway, reducing airway obstruction.

    Question Category
    Concept

    Taurodontism is defined as a dental anomaly in which the pulpal floor and furcation are shifted more apical that normal, resulting in an elongated pulp chamber and shorter roots, as seen in the image below. This finding is associated with a number of syndromes including Down’s Syndrome, ectodermal dysplasia, and Klinefelter Syndrome, but not DiGeorge Syndrome.

    DiGeorge syndrome is a relatively uncommon immunodeficiency that may occur either in the presence or absence of craniofacial abnormalities, but it is not associated with taurodontism. DiGeorge syndrome, also known as velocardiofacial syndrome, is a congenital syndrome characterized by failure of the 3rd and 4th pharyngeal pouches to develop thus causing absent thymus (low T cell counts) and parathyroids (low serum TSH and Ca2+ levels), as well as cardiac, palate, and facial defects. It is caused by a 22q11 microdeletion and is far less common than solitary cleft lip and/or cleft palate. 

    Therefore, C is the correct answer.

  • 109.  Each of the following is a complication of Sjögren disease EXCEPT one. Which one is the EXCEPTION?
    Incorrect
    The correct answer is: D.
    47%
    Answered Correctly
    0 min, 3 secs
    Time Spent
    Question Category
    Concept

    Sjögren disease is an autoimmune disorder that affects the exocrine glandular epithelium, predominantly the lacrimal and salivary glands. The most common symptoms are keratoconjunctivitis sicca (dry eyes) and xerostomia (dry mouth). This condition was formerly known as Sjögren’s syndrome. Sjögren disease is classified as ‘primary’ when it is the single most autoimmune disease present and ‘secondary’ when at least one other autoimmune disease is associated with it. Due to higher levels of immunoglobulins present in the blood, the erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) is increased. Other conditions which can increase the ESR are systemic inflammation, infections, anemias, cancers, pregnancy, thyroid disorders, etc. 

    Therefore, D is the correct answer. 

    Process of Elimination

    Option A is incorrect, as anemia, often in a mild form, is a complication associated with Sjögren disease. It occurs due to the presence of chronic inflammation in the body affecting the regulation of red blood cells. 

    Option B is incorrect, as joint pain is a complication associated with Sjögren disease, primarily due to the presence of rheumatoid arthritis, which is another musculoskeletal autoimmune disease. 

    Option C is incorrect, as lymphoma, especially B-cell lymphoma, has a 15-20 times higher risk in people with Sjögren disease than in normal populations.

  • 111. Each of the following is a component of the STOP-BANG questionnaire for obstructive sleep apnea (OSA) EXCEPT one. Which one is the EXCEPTION?
    Incorrect
    The correct answer is: C.
    76%
    Answered Correctly
    0 min, 2 secs
    Time Spent
    Question Category
    Concept

    Obstructive sleep apnea (OSA) is the most common form of sleep apnea, constituting almost 80% of the sleep-related disorders in the U.S. population. It is characterized by a recurrent collapse of the upper airway during sleep which results in partial or complete stoppage of airflow despite the best respiratory efforts of the patient. Many risk factors are responsible for causing obstructive sleep apnea, and a STOP-BANG questionnaire is used to screen this condition. It consists of an eight-question checklist of signs and symptoms of obstructive sleep apnea. Answering yes to less than three of the eight points places a person at low risk while answering yes to three or more points puts a person at a high risk of obstructive sleep apnea. One of the important components of this questionnaire is being male. Males are more prone to developing obstructive sleep apnea as compared to females. The image below shows a STOP-BANG questionnaire screening tool for obstructive sleep apnea.

    Therefore, C is the correct answer.

    (Image Courtesy – Silva NEVES JUNIOR et al. September 2020 Arquivos de Neuro-psiquiatria 78(9):561-569, CC BY-SA 4.0)

    Process of Elimination

    Option A is incorrect, as tiredness, fatigue, or sleepiness during daytime is a component of the STOP-BANG questionnaire.

    Option B is incorrect, as a Body Mass Index (BMI) of more than 35 kg/m2 is a component of the STOP-BANG questionnaire.

    Option D is incorrect, as high blood pressure constitutes a component of the STOP-BANG questionnaire, whether a person has it or is being treated for it.

    114. Which condition is the patient likely suffering from?
    Incorrect

    64%

    Time Spent
    Question Category
    Concept

    Dental abscesses can result from several usual causes like pulpal necrosis, bacterial ingression, and immunosuppressed states with a focal nidus of infection intraorally. One of the unusual conditions where spontaneous dental abscess formation can be seen is the inherited disorder of phosphate metabolism, X-linked hypophosphatemia, also known as vitamin D-resistant rickets. This condition typically results in teeth having enlarged pulp chambers with pulp horns reaching the dentinoenamel junction. Due to structural defects in enamel and dentin, these teeth wear out early, and the pulp horns get exposed, leading to the formation of dental abscesses. Patients often exhibit an early loss of teeth, especially the primary teeth, delayed tooth eruption, and hypoplastic alveolar ridges. Other features of vitamin D-resistant rickets include bone pain, short stature, bowed legs, impaired growth, and hearing loss. Given this patient’s presenting signs and symptoms, a diagnosis of X-linked hypophosphatemia can be arrived at. 

    Therefore, D is the correct answer.

    Option B is incorrect, as hyperphosphatemia is characterized by abnormally high phosphate levels in the blood. Clinical symptoms include tetany, tingling, muscle cramps, pruritus, joint pain, and rashes. 

    Option C is incorrect, as osteomalacia occurs due to the deficiency of vitamin D in adults resulting in the formation of poorly mineralized bone. Patients often suffer from bone pain, fractures due to minor injuries, and muscle weakness.

    Question Category
    Concept

    The most common symptom of hypoglycemia is irritability. Hypoglycemia is when the blood glucose level drops below the range the body is used to. The exact number varies slightly for everyone but the American Diabetes Association states that hypoglycemia occurs usually when the blood glucose level drops below 70mg/dL. The most common cause is when a patient with diabetes takes their medication but forgets to eat their meal. Common signs and symptoms of hypoglycemia include feeling shaky, sweating, irritability, confusion, fast heartbeat, lightheaded, hunger, pale face and nausea. In the dental setting, treatment for hypoglycemia include oral glucose sources (such as a juice box or glucose tablets) if the patient is conscious or intramuscular glucagon injections if the patient is unconscious.

    Therefore, A is the correct answer.

    Option C is incorrect as a thirst is a sign of ketoacidosis which may occur in patients with poorly controlled diabetes.

    Option D is incorrect as a flushed face is a sign of ketoacidosis which may occur in patients with poorly controlled diabetes.

    122. Which condition can the patient’s medical history most likely contribute to?
    Incorrect
    The correct answer is: B.
    83%
    Answered Correctly
    0 min, 0 secs
    Time Spent
    Question Category
    Concept

    Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) is a type of obstructive lung disease that results in limited airflow. COPD encompasses emphysema and chronic bronchitis, which overlap clinically and oftentimes present together. Emphysema involves damaged and enlarged alveoli/air spaces, as illustrated in the image below. This condition can be acquired typically due to smoking. Chronic bronchitis involves a persistent cough and mucous production as a result of chronic irritation to the airway, which also commonly occurs due to smoking. Some symptoms of COPD include a chronic cough, mucous production, and dyspnea. To slow the progression of the disease, it is best for a person currently smoking to cease smoking. Although this patient is not a current smoker, based on the history of long-term smoking, COPD is the most likely condition present.

    Therefore, B is the correct answer

    (Image Courtesy – Blausen Medical Communications, Inc., 2013, CC BY 3.0)

    Process of Elimination

    Option A is incorrect because, although bronchiectasis is also an obstructive lung disease, it is typically caused by chronic infection and/or bronchial obstruction (e.g., by a foreign body or tumour). The result is permanent airway dilation due to damaged airway tissue.

    Option C is incorrect because pneumoconiosis is a restrictive lung disease associated with the inhalation of various dusts or fumes that subsequently deposit in the lungs and lead to collagen formation and fibrosis. This condition is often associated with occupational hazards (e.g., dental lab technicians being exposed to sandblasting).

    Option D is incorrect because idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis is a restrictive lung disease that involves progressive shortness of breath. This type of pulmonary fibrosis may be associated with several factors, including viral infection, hereditary factors, and exposure to tobacco smoke. However, the exact etiology is typically unknown. Treatment is eventually a lung transplant due to respiratory failure.

    Gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) is a condition in which gastric acid travels up the esophagus.     124. If the patient’s father is unaffected and the mother is a carrier, what is the probability of a female sibling being a carrier?
    Incorrect
    The correct answer is: C.
    53%
    Answered Correctly
    0 min, 0 secs
    Time Spent
    Question Category
    Concept

    Females have two X chromosomes and males have one X and one Y. X-linked recessive disorders are expressed in females only if the variant occurs in both copies of the gene (one on each X chromosome). However, for males, one copy of the altered copy of the gene is sufficient to cause the condition. With the father unaffected, each female sibling born to a carrier mother of an X-linked recessive trait has a 50% chance of being a carrier. Each male sibling born to a carrier mother with an X-linked recessive trait has a 50% chance of being affected.

    Therefore, C is the correct answer.

    (Image courtesy – Unknown, CC BY-SA 4.0)

    Process of Elimination

    Option A is incorrect because with the father unaffected, each female sibling born to a carrier mother of an X-linked recessive trait has a 50% chance of being a carrier.

    Option B is incorrect because with the father unaffected, each female sibling born to a carrier mother of an X-linked recessive trait has a 50% chance of being a carrier.

    Option D is incorrect because with the father unaffected, each female sibling born to a carrier mother of an X-linked recessive trait has a 50% chance of being a carrier.

  • 126. Which is not involved in Ludwig’s angina?
    Incorrect
    The correct answer is: C.
    74%
    Answered Correctly
    0 min, 0 secs
    Time Spent
    Question Category
    Concept

    Retropharyngeal space infection usually occurs following a soft tissue infection of the throat because of upper respiratory tract infections and retropharyngeal trauma. This condition is most common in children under five years old. The anatomic boundaries of the retropharyngeal space are the buccopharyngeal fascia anteriorly and the alar fascia posteriorly. The space spans from the skull base superiorly and the mediastinum inferiorly. Symptoms of retropharyngeal space infection include neck stiffness, bulging of the posterior pharyngeal wall, sore throat, dysphagia, and dyspnea. It is not traditionally involved in Ludwig’s angina.

    Ludwig’s angina is a potentially life-threatening bacterial infection of the mandibular floor and neck. It involves three compartments of the floor of the mouth, the submental space, the sublingual space, and the submandibular space. It often develops after an infection of the roots of mandibular teeth (particularly the second and third molars) or a mouth injury. The infection is a rapidly progressing indurated cellulitis that can potentially lead to airway obstruction. Common symptoms include swelling of the floor of the mouth, protruding/swollen tongue, neck swelling/pain, toothache, dysphagia, and dyspnea. The treatment of Ludwig’s angina focuses on airway protection, elimination of the source of infection (i.e., extraction of the offending tooth), controlling the infection with antibiotic therapy, and surgical drainage in cases of suppurative infection.

    Therefore, C is the correct answer.

    (Image courtesy – Hulkarni, et al., CC BY 2.0)

    127. After impressions are taken, the patient’s upper and lower lip immediately swell. What is the most likely diagnosis?
    Incorrect
    The correct answer is: A.
    74%
    Answered Correctly
    0 min, 0 secs
    Time Spent
    Question Category
    Concept

    Angioedema is characterized by subcutaneous/submucosal nonpitting edema affecting the lips, face, neck, extremities, and gastrointestinal tract. Angioedema may develop as an acute allergic reaction, precipitated by allergens including medications, foods, and even dental materials (e.g., impression material), which results in characteristic non-erythematous swelling of the lips, face, and neck. Moderate to severe symptoms are typically managed with antihistamines and anti-inflammatory medications.

    Therefore, A is the correct answer.

    (Image courtesy – Boussetta, et al., CC BY 4.0)

    Process of Elimination

    Option B is incorrect because asthma is a chronic inflammatory disease of the airways characterized by reversible airflow obstruction and easily triggered bronchospasm in response to various stimuli. Common symptoms of asthma include wheezing, coughing, shortness of breath, and chest tightness.

    Option C is incorrect because granulomatous cheilitis is a chronic noncaseating granulomatous inflammatory condition that causes persistent idiopathic swelling of the lip. When it is paired with a fissured tongue and facial paralysis, it is specifically referred to as Melkersson-Rosenthal syndrome.

    Option D is incorrect because anaphylaxis is a potentially life-threatening systemic allergic reaction due to the sudden systemic release of mediators from mast cells and basophils, stimulated by allergen cross-linking of membrane-bound specific IgE antibodies (type 1 hypersensitivity). Common features include facial swelling (e.g. angioedema, periorbital edema), urticaria, respiratory compromise, hypotension, and gastrointestinal discomfort. Angioedema may occur as a part of an anaphylactic reaction or may occur alone and should be distinguished from the multi-system response of anaphylaxis.

    Question Category
    Concept

    Human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) is a retrovirus with genetic material comprised of single-stranded RNA. Its main mode of transmission is by exchange of infected bodily fluids such as blood, semen, breastmilk, and vaginal secretions.

    HIV primarily infects cells that possess CD4 cell-surface receptor molecules such as the CD4+ T cells. Once within the cell, the retrovirus releases its RNA and synthesizes double-stranded DNA using the enzyme reverse transcriptase. HIV integrase inserts the newly synthesized DNA into the host cell genomic DNA where creation of mRNA allows for production of viral proteins. The image below shows the process of HIV entry into host cells from the binding of HIV molecule gp120 to CD4 cell-surface receptors and HIV molecule gp41 mediating membrane fusion.

  • 130. Which neurotransmitter causes mucous secretion in airway epithelial cells?
    Incorrect
    The correct answer is: A.
    86%
    Answered Correctly
    0 min, 0 secs
    Time Spent
    Question Category
    Concept

    Acetylcholine causes mucous secretion in airway epithelial cells. Acetylcholine is the neurotransmitter that binds to cholinergic receptors which are located on parasympathetic effector organs. Acetylcholine is synthesized by the enzyme choline acetyltransferase through combining acetyl CoA and choline and degraded by the enzyme acetylcholinesterase. Illustrated below is a simplified image of acetylcholine transport and synthesis at the cholinergic synapse.

    Acetylcholine is the predominant parasympathetic neurotransmitter in the airway that regulates bronchoconstriction and mucous secretion. When parasympathetic nerves are stimulated, acetylcholine is released and acts directly on the muscarinic receptors on the airway smooth muscle cells to cause bronchoconstriction and submucosal glands to cause mucous secretion.

    Therefore, A is the correct answer.

    (Image Courtesy – Smedlib, based on original work by Pancrat, CC BY-SA 4.0, via Wikimedia Commons)

    Process of Elimination

    Option B is incorrect as serotonin does not cause mucous secretion in airway epithelial cells. Serotonin is a neurotransmitter involved in mood modulation, sleep, memory, and other physiological processes.

    Option C is incorrect as dopamine does not cause mucous secretion in airway epithelial cells. Dopamine is a neurotransmitter involved in many body functions including the reward pathway, motivation, and memory.

    Option D is incorrect as GABA does not cause mucous secretion in airway epithelial cells. GABA is the primary inhibitory neurotransmitter in the brain and a major inhibitory neurotransmitter in the spinal cord.

    131. Which test would the dentist request to assess the patient’s ability to form a clot?
    Incorrect
    The correct answer is: D.
    58%
    Answered Correctly
    0 min, 0 secs
    Time Spent
    Question Category
    Concept

    PTT will assess this patient’s ability to form a clot. PTT stands for partial thromboplastin time and this test measures the patient’s ability to form a blood clot in seconds. This is used to measure the activity of the intrinsic pathway and the common pathway of the coagulation cascade. Illustrated below is the coagulation cascade. Heparin is anticoagulant and mainly inhibits factor Xa and IIa.  However, it can also inhibit factor IXa, Xia and XIIa which are components of the intrinsic pathway. Ultimately, when components of the coagulation cascade are inhibited, fibrinogen will not be converted to fibrin and a clot will not form.

    Therefore, D is the correct answer.

    Option B is incorrect as CBC would not be used by the dentist to assess the patient’s ability to form a clot.

    Option C is incorrect as bleeding time would not be used by the dentist to assess the patient’s ability to form a clot.

  • 132. Which represents the pathophysiology of Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus?
    Incorrect
    The correct answer is: A.
    88%
    Answered Correctly
    0 min, 0 secs
    Time Spent
    Question Category
    Concept

    Type 2 diabetes mellitus is characterized by hyperglycemia, insulin resistance and insulin secretion impairment. Insulin resistance is when cells in muscle, fat and liver don’t respond to insulin. The result of this is that glucose cannot be taken up from the blood. In turn, the pancreas makes more insulin to get glucose into cells. In diabetes, the insulin becomes ineffective. In type 1 diabetes, there is a destruction of insulin-producing beta cells.

    Type II diabetes symptoms include polyuria, polydipsia and polyphagia. Other symptoms are shown in the image below. Controlling diabetes through diet and medications is very important in reducing fatigue, bladder issues and long-term complications such as vision loss and kidney disease.

    Therefore, A is the correct answer.

    (Image Courtesy – Häggström, 2012, CC BY-SA 3.0)

    Process of Elimination

    Option B is incorrect because beta cell dysfunction and destruction occurs in type 1 diabetes.

    Option C is incorrect because alpha cell dysfunction can occur in type II diabetes, but it is through the process of eventually becoming resistant to insulin.

    Option D is incorrect because antidiuretic hormone deficiency occurs in diabetes insipidus, not type II diabetes.

    Concept

    Type 1 diabetes is characterized by the autoimmune destruction of the beta-cells in the pancreas which produce insulin. Signs and symptoms Type 1 diabetes may include polydipsia, weight loss, polyuria, and polyphagia.     143. Which blood test would provide a definitive diagnosis for the chief complaint?
    Incorrect
    The correct answer is: B.
    81%
    Answered Correctly
    0 min, 0 secs
    Time Spent
    Question Category
    Concept

    International normalized ratio (INR) would provide a definitive diagnosis for the chief complaint. Many patients take aspirin 81 mg as an antiplatelet drug to prevent heart attack and stroke. One of the potential side effects of baby aspirin is increased bleeding. However, being on warfarin puts the patient at a higher risk of bleeding. Patients on warfarin therapy should have close monitoring to ensure the safety and efficacy of the medication, which includes monitoring how long it takes for the patient’s blood to clot. The risk of bleeding is significantly greater with increased INR, especially if it is above 5.0. The patient’s chief complaint of his gums bleeding easily could indicate that his INR is too high. The image below shows the inhibition of vitamin K epoxide reductase by warfarin, which inhibits the formation of the active form of vitamin K.

    Therefore, B is the correct answer.

    (Image Courtesy- Kalaimani Elango et al, CC BY 4.0)

    Process of Elimination

    Option A is incorrect because platelet count would not provide a definitive diagnosis for the chief complaint. A platelet count would be ordered for a patient suspected of having thrombocytopenia or thrombocytosis or may be used to monitor a patient on antiplatelet therapy.

    Option C is incorrect because partial thromboplastin time (PTT) would not provide a definitive diagnosis for the chief complaint. PTT is used to check the intrinsic and common pathways in the clotting cascade and is most commonly used for patients on heparin.

    Option D is incorrect because clotting time (CT) would not provide a definitive diagnosis for the chief complaint. CT is used mostly to diagnose hemophilia. It has lost its importance due to the development of different, more effective tests.

    Concept

    Confusion is a common symptom of hypoglycemia. Other common symptoms of hypoglycemia include fatigue, behavioral changes, fast heartbeat, shaking, sweating, pallor, dizziness, and hunger. The other answer choices would be associated with hyperglycemia, or in the case of fruity smell on the breath, diabetic ketoacidosis. The image below highlights different consequences of hypoglycemia.

    Therefore, C is the correct answer.

    (Image Courtesy- Stephanie Amiel, CC BY 4.0)

  • 145. Which test measures the blood sugar before and after the consumption of glucose?
    Incorrect
    The correct answer is: D.
    50%
    Answered Correctly
    0 min, 0 secs
    Time Spent
    Question Category
    Concept

    The glucose tolerance test measures blood sugar before and after the patient drinks a liquid containing glucose. This test is performed by having the patient fast overnight to determine the fasting blood sugar level. The patient then drinks a liquid containing glucose and blood sugar levels are checked at one hour, two hours, and potentially three hours after consumption if necessary.

    Given the nature of this test, the blood sugar levels are determined both before and after the consumption of glucose. For the glucose tolerance test, 140 mg/dL or below is normal. Prediabetes is measured between 140-199 mg/dL on the glucose tolerance test, while diabetes is measured at 200 mg/dL or above.

    Therefore, D is the correct answer.

    Process of Elimination

    Option A is incorrect because the A1C test measures a three-month average of blood sugar. For the A1C Test, below 5.7% is normal, 5.7-6.4% is prediabetic, and above 6.5% is considered diabetic.

    Option B is incorrect because the fasting blood sugar test measures blood sugar after an overnight fast. For the fasting blood sugar test, below 99 mg/dL is normal, 100-125 mg/dL is prediabetic, and above 126 mg/dL is considered diabetic.

    Option C is incorrect because the glucose screening test measures blood sugar at the time of the test. It is typical for the patient to drink a liquid containing glucose and have the test completed one hour later. For the glucose screening test, 140 mg/dL or lower is normal. If the test results in higher than 140 mg/dL, a glucose tolerance test is recommended.

  • 146. Each of the following conditions should be included in the differential diagnosis of Sjögren disease EXCEPT one. Which is the EXCEPTION?
    Incorrect
    The correct answer is: C.
    56%
    Answered Correctly
    0 min, 0 secs
    Time Spent
    Question Category
    Concept

    Sjögren disease is a chronic autoimmune disease that is identified by the common symptoms of dry eyes and dry mouth. Additional symptoms may include parotid gland enlargement, musculoskeletal pain, and fatigue. Although dry eyes and dry mouth are the most common symptoms of Sjögren disease, there may also be drying with the following: skin, nose, sinuses, throat, ears, and vagina.

    Differential diagnosis of Sjögren disease includes conditions and medications that produce similar symptoms to that of Sjögren disease. For example, dry mouth may be caused by amyloidosis, sarcoidosis, diabetes mellitus, viral infections, irradiation, trauma, or may be psychogenic. Furthermore, the following drugs may produce xerostomia: antihypertensive, parasympatholytic, and psychotherapeutic agents. Dry eyes may be caused by amyloidosis, inflammation, neurological conditions, sarcoidosis, toxicity, and a variegation of other conditions. Bilateral parotid gland enlargement may be caused by endocrine disorders, metabolic diseases, or viral infections. Differential diagnosis is important in eliminating other systemic disorders and identifying Sjögren disease for early treatment of complications.

    Fibrosarcoma is a rare soft tissue sarcoma affecting fibroblasts. Risk factors for developing fibrosarcoma include the following: weakened lymph system, radiation or chemical exposure, and inherited genetic abnormalities. While symptoms may be hard to identify fibrosarcoma, scans such as CT, MRI, ultrasound, and PET help to determine a diagnosis. Additionally, x-rays and biopsies aid in diagnosis. Fibrosarcoma is not included in the differential diagnosis of Sjögren disease.

    Therefore, C is the correct answer.

    (Image Courtesy – Scientific Animations 2018, CC BY-SA 4.0)

    Process of Elimination

    Option A is incorrect because amyloidosis is a differential diagnosis for Sjögren disease. Amyloidosis is a condition in which amyloid proteins build up in the heart, kidney, liver, and other organs causing deposits and subsequent damage.

    Option B is incorrect because sarcoidosis is a differential diagnosis for Sjögren disease. Sarcoidosis is a condition in which inflammatory cells abnormally collect and form granulomas in the lungs, skin, or lymph nodes.

    Option D is incorrect because scleroderma is a differential diagnosis for Sjögren disease. Scleroderma is a group of rare diseases in which overproduction of collagen causes hardening and tightening of skin and other connective tissues.

  • Patient
    Male, 78 years old
    Chief Complaint
    “I am here for a cleaning.”
    Background and/or Patient History

    History of Alzheimer disease

    Current Findings

    BP: 130/82
    Temp: 97.9

    Impaired language function and executive ability.

    147. Which is the most likely stage of this patient’s Alzheimer's disease?
    Incorrect
    The correct answer is: B.
    43%
    Answered Correctly
    0 min, 0 secs
    Time Spent
    Question Category
    Concept

    Alzheimer’s disease is a neurodegenerative disorder distinguished by neurofibrillary tangles, amyloid plaques, and atrophy of the posterior part of the brain as seen in the image below. Dementia is a general term to describe cognitive decline severe enough to interfere with daily life activities. Alzheimer disease is the most common type of dementia and accounts for at least two-thirds of dementia cases in people 65 years of age and older. Alzheimer’s disease symptoms depend on the stage of the disease with the following classifications: preclinical or presymptomatic, mild cognitive impairment, and dementia.

    Mild cognitive impairment stage is identified with individuals who have impairment in executive ability or language function. Despite this impairment, these individuals continue to work, socialize, and function independently.

    Therefore, B is the correct answer.

    (Image Courtesy – Breijyeh & Karaman 2020, CC BY 4.0)

    Process of Elimination

    Option A is incorrect because the preclinical stage is identified with individuals who are asymptomatic with definite laboratory evidence. Biomarkers are identified in this stage to help diagnose Alzheimer’s disease.

    Option C is incorrect because the presymptomatic stage is equivalent to the preclinical stage of Alzheimer’s disease, which is not the description of this patient.

    Option D is incorrect because the dementia stage is identified with individuals who have incapacitating memory impairment. There are significant language changes as well as impairment of visuospatial abilities and loss of normal circadian sleep-wake patterns.

  • 148. Which is a sign or symptom of a patient with myxedema coma?
    Incorrect
    The correct answer is: D.
    72%
    Answered Correctly
    0 min, 0 secs
    Time Spent
    Question Category
    Concept

    Myxedema coma is a rare and life-threatening complication of hypothyroidism that can result from any cause of hypothyroidism. It is characterized by altered sensorium and multiple organ abnormalities. Factors such as infections, trauma, and drugs can overwhelm the homeostatic mechanisms in hypothyroid patients and lead to myxedema coma. The mortality rate varies between 20 to 60% even with intensive care. Early recognition, diagnosis, and treatment with intravenous levothyroxine and hydrocortisone are important for the longevity and health of the patient. A thorough history, physical exam, and early treatment are essential in managing this condition. Bradycardia can be a sign of hypothyroidism and myxedema coma. Other signs and symptoms are shown in the image below.

    Therefore, D is the correct answer.

    (Image Courtesy – Public Domain, 10 January 2014. CC BY 3.0)

    Process of Elimination

    Option A is incorrect because excessive thyroid hormone production can come from hyperthyroidism, not hypothyroidism.

    Option B is incorrect because weight loss typically is a result of hyperthyroidism. The opposite may occur in hypothyroidism and myxedema coma.

    Option C is incorrect because tachycardia, fast heart rate, is a sign of hyperthyroidism. Myxedema coma can cause bradycardia.
